Philadelphia Jack O'Brien [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163722564/] In December 1920 Tex Rickard announced he was building the world's largest gym in Madison Square Garden (including, in the summer, the world's largest pool) and that Philadelphia Jack O'Brien would be the "physical director". The 1/5th mile track ran around the roof of the old MSG.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Thank you for the information on O'Brien and Rickard. Would you have a source that shows the construction date of the track as 1920? I'm able to confirm everything else for the catalog record, but that would allow us to establish a better date for the photograph.

This photo appeared in the Boston Evening Globe, Wednesday, December 29, 1920 - Page 13. In the accompanying picture Harvey Cohn and Philadelphia Jack O'Brien are seen ready to start off on a long jaunt" Cohn was a former member of the Irish Amateur Athletic Club who competed in the Olympics in St. Louis in 1904, 1906 in Athens and 1908 in London. He coached at Indiana and Colby. He coached the Japanese team at the Antwerp Olympics in 1920. His gig atop the Garden didn't last long, as by the summer of 1921 he was announced as the new coach at New Hampshire. O'Brien announced in 1922 that he was ending his association with the Garden and opening another gym on Broadway.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Thank you! The additional identification of Cohn is greatly appreciated.

Seems to be Marie Sims, daughter of Thetus Willrette Sims (April 25, 1852 – December 17, 1939), member of the United States House of Representatives for the 8th congressional district of Tennessee (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetus_W._Sims). The Evening star. [volume], December 19, 1920, Page 4 printed a photo of her with the caption: "MRS. EDWARD GARRICK RIDDICK, Who before her marriage a week ago was Miss Marie Sims." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-12-19/ed-... The same woman IMO. Other sources indicate that the name of her husband was Edward Garrett Riddick, s. e.g. - Evening star. [volume], December 12, 1920, Page 4, col. 3 & 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-12-12/ed-... - The Richmond palladium and sun-telegram., November 04, 1920, Page 5 (photo) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86058226/1920-11-04/ed-...

Thank you for the sleuthing. I believe this is the proper identification. Her husband's correct name appears to be Edward Garrett Riddick as found in a 1911 Vanderbilt University roster and a 1918 American Bar Association directory.

Franz Lehár (Hungarian: Lehár Ferenc; 30 April 1870 – 24 October 1948) was an Austro-Hungarian composer. He is mainly known for his operettas, of which the most successful and best known is The Merry Widow (Die lustige Witwe). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_Leh%C3%A1r

Philipp Heinrich Scheidemann (26 July 1865 – 29 November 1939) was a German politician of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD). On 9 November 1918, in the midst of the German Revolution of 1918–1919, he proclaimed Germany a republic. Later, beginning in the early part of the following year, he became the second head of government of the Weimar Republic, acting in this post for 127 days. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Scheidemann

The Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani is a monastery near Bardstown, Kentucky, in Nelson County, a part of the Order of Cistercians of the Strict Observance (Ordo Cisterciensis Strictioris Observantiae), better known as the Trappists. Founded on 21 December 1848 and raised to an abbey in 1851, Gethsemani is considered to be the motherhouse of all Trappist and Trappistine monasteries in the United States of America. Gethsemani is the oldest monastery in the United States that is still operating. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbey_of_Our_Lady_of_Gethsemani
Thanks, Richard Norton, for directing us to the Abbey.

"Marie Dolores Eliza Rosanna Gilbert, Countess of Landsfeld[1] (17 February 1821 – 17 January 1861), better known by the stage name Lola Montez (/moʊnˈtɛz/), was an Irish dancer and actress who became famous as a "Spanish dancer", courtesan, and mistress of King Ludwig I of Bavaria, who made her Countess of Landsfeld. She used her influence to institute liberal reforms. At the start of the Revolutions of 1848 in the German states, she was forced to flee. She proceeded to the United States via Switzerland, France and London, returning to her work as an entertainer and lecturer." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lola_Montez

"These Milk Bottles in Spokane were designed in 1934 by Whitehouse and Price. They stand 38 feet tall and are 15 feet wide. The body of the bottles are wood and wire mesh covered with stucco. The neck and cap are sheet metal over a wooden frame. The owner, Paul E. Newport, had six or seven of these milk bottles built as retail outlets for his Benewah Dairy Company. The bottles were designed to make milk appealing to children. The company folded in 1972 and only these two bottles remain. Another on Perry St. was converted into a windmill but seems to be gone." www.roadarch.com/vessels/milk.html

The evening world., December 02, 1920 ran a picture of Margaret Warren with the caption: "MARGARET WARREN TO BECOME BRIDE IN ST. THOMAS'S, JAN. 22 Colonel's Daughter and General's Son Fix the Date of Their Union. St. Thomas's Church Is the place and Jan. 22 the date selected for the marriage of Miss Margaret R. Warren, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Charles Ellott Warren of No. 114 East 36th Street, and Shannon Lord Meany, son of General and Mrs. Edward P. Meany of Convent, N. J. Margaret Morris (1888-1966) was a dancer and performed in numerous Ziegfeld Follies productions beginning in 1910. Family members said she was discovered by Florence Ziegfeld dancing on a New York City street corner. She performed in both the Follies of 1912, 1913 and 1920 and in Ziegfield's famed Midnight Frolic atop the New Amsterdam Theatre in 1915 and 1920. Margaret also performed in Ziegfeld's musicals "Miss 1917" and "The Century Girl" in 1917. Margaret was in at least one silent movie, "The Gypsys". In later years she worked in wardrobe on Broadway and was a long time member of the Ziegfeld Club. – Compiled  [1] [2] [3] Not to be confused with Margaret Morris (1891-1980) a British dancer. [4]

This is Dr. Esther Clayson Pohl Lovejoy: "Esther Pohl Lovejoy (November 16, 1869 – August 31, 1967) was an American physician and public health pioneer, suffrage activist, congressional candidate, and a central figure in early efforts to organize international medical relief work. In 1907, Lovejoy became the first woman appointed to direct a department of health in a major U.S city, the Portland Board of Health, Oregon. Lovejoy worked on the women's suffrage campaigns in Oregon in 1906 and 1912, and founded the Everybody's Equal Suffrage League ahead of the 1912 election, when Oregon became the 7th state to grant women the right to vote. Lovejoy was among the founders of the Medical Women's International Association and was elected as its first president in 1919. Lovejoy ran for the U.S. Congress in 1920 as the Democratic candidate for Portland’s Third District but was not successful against the sitting Republican.] She was awarded the Elizabeth Blackwell Medal by the American Medical Women's Association in 1951 and 1957 for contributions to the field of medicine." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esther_Pohl_Lovejoy The date on the negative is 10/26/10. The embossed photographer's imprint says Portland, Oregon.

"Perry" Bottriell (US Army Air Service) (b. 1885 - d. 1943), tested experimental parachutes for the Air Service, including the first successful test of a free-fall backpack parachute on May 19, 1919. Bottriell, then a master sergeant in charge of the Parachute Section at Kelly Field, Texas, was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross on March 18, 1932." Built in France in 1919 books.google.com/books?id=9y8cBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA267 "The Zodiac ZDUS-1 and ZDUS-2 were ordered by the Navy and shipped to the US. Never operated by the Navy they were both apparently transferred to the Army, and one, the ZDUS-1, was operated by the Army at Langley Field, where the name was changed to ZD-1 and then to RN-1. The RN-1 was rebuilt with a significantly modified and lightened control car and two Liberty engines replacing the Renaults. In 1923 the RN-1 was rebuilt at Scott Field (Oklahoma). A new 340,000-cubic-foot (9,600 m3) envelope was provided, the control car was further modified and the two Liberty engines were replaced by Packards. RN-1 was put in storage at Scott Field during 1924. Scrapping followed." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_blimps_operated_by_the_USN S. also photos in - New-York tribune., October 17, 1920, Page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-10-17/ed-... - New-York tribune., October 24, 1920, Image 53 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-10-24/ed-...

"The Greyhound Bus Depot is Columbia’s finest example of Art Moderne architecture. This style, popular from about 1930 until 1941, was derived from the pioneering work of industrial designers such as Norman Bel Geddes, Henry Dreyfuss, and Raymond Loewy. The primary elements of the style were the extensive use of new materials, such as aluminum, stainless steel, and synthetics; the absence of superfluous ornament; the suppression of functional demands beneath an encompassing shell; and the extensive use of streamlining, especially in buildings associated with transportation. The depot is an island-type bus station which was built in 1938-1939. The building has a full basement with reinforced concrete foundations and a structural steel framework supporting its main level. George D. Brown, the architect of the Columbia Bus Depot, used design motifs introduced by the industrial designer Raymond Loewy. Loewy had prepared designs for Greyhound from 1933, and was responsible for the blue and ivory color scheme, the stainless steel trim, the redesign of the running dog, and the aerodynamic streamlining, all of which were incorporated into the company image. Loewy’s designs for Greyhound Busses utilized these elements. The Art Moderne was significant as a symbol of hope during the Great Depression. The style represented speed, efficiency, and industrial prosperity, overcoming the economic hardships of the era. Listed in the National Register December 28, 1989." South Carolina Department of Archives and History
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greyhound_Bus_Depot_(Columbia,_South_Carolina) Streetview

House of Representatives from Nebraska's Third District. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89074443/1920-07-05/ed-... www.herhatwasinthering.org/biography.php?id=7463 S. also www.usgennet.org/usa/ne/topic/resources/OLLibrary/who1940...: "WEEKES, MRS MARIE: Postmaster; b Cuming Co, Neb May 6, 1881; d of James O'Donnell-Katherine McLaughlin; ed West Point HS 1900; Fremont Normal; m William Herbert Weekes Oct 2, 1907 Geneva (dec Sept 25, 1927); foster s Bryan P, Ralph, Charles H, William H; foster d Anna (Mrs George Werner), Gertrude (Mrs C Schaffer); 1904-07 with West Point newspaper; 1908-09 on Fremont News; 1909-31 publisher Norfolk Press; 1934 P M Norfolk; editor of The Nebraska Postmaster, published by Neb ch of Natl Assns of PMs of US, 1st state secy of orgn; VP Norfolk Livestock Sales Co; past pres NPA; Tri-State Editorial Assn; twice past pres & founder NE Neb Editorial Assn, only woman to serve in these offices; author & sponsor Neb Writers Guild; past pres NS&D of Neb; first woman Indep candidate for Congress 1920; apptd by Gov McMullen to represent Neb at Woman's Worlds Fair in Chicago 1927 as Nebraska's outstanding woman; state food & hotel inspector 1917-18; clk Indian com congress 1934, & C of C; off P O; res 113 Madison Ave, Norfolk."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_R._Brinkley "John Romulus Brinkley (later John Richard Brinkley; July 8, 1885 – May 26, 1942) was an American who fraudulently claimed to be a medical doctor (he had no legitimate medical education and bought his medical degree from a "diploma mill") who became known as the "goat-gland doctor" after he achieved national fame, international notoriety and great wealth through the xenotransplantation of goat testicles into humans. Although initially Brinkley promoted this procedure as a means of curing male impotence, eventually he claimed that the technique was a virtual panacea for a wide range of male ailments. He operated clinics and hospitals in several states, and despite the fact that almost from the beginning, detractors and critics in the medical community thoroughly discredited his methods, he was able to continue his activities for almost two decades." See photo in Arizona Republican., February 20, 1920, Annual Cotton Edition, Section 2, Page 4, Image 14, column 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020558/1920-02-20/ed-...

2 other photos from the likely same photo session by Kansas photographer Joseph J. Pennell. luna.ku.edu/luna/servlet/detail/kuluna01kui~15~15~2493305... Pennell seems to have documented Dr. Brinkley's operation: luna.ku.edu/luna/servlet/view/search;JSESSIONID=1ecffb00-...

Evelyn Scotney (11 July 1896 – 5 August 1967), Australian coloratura soprano en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Scotney

She was singing at the Met in 1920. See archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WS... According to operalady.blogspot.com/2009/08/enrico-caruso-o-sole-mio-a... "On December 11, 1920, during a performance of L'elisir d'amore by Donizetti at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, he had suffered a throat haemorrhage and the audience was dismissed at the end of Act 1. Following this incident, a clearly unwell Caruso gave only three more performances at the Met, the final one being in the role of Eléazar in Halévy's La Juive, on Christmas Eve 1920. (Appearing in the cast that night was the Australian-born coloratura soprano, Evelyn Scotney, who had sung with Caruso a number of times before.)" She also toured with the Scotti Opera Company in 1920. See Music Magazine of May 27, 1920 books.google.com/books?id=y-w6AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA22-PA36&a... Her earlier career at the Boston Opera is shown at findingaids.library.columbia.edu/ead/nnc-rb/ldpd_4079423/

The neighboring photos of "MIscha Violin," e.g., look younger (and with a bit more hair) than the pictures of Mischa Elman from considerably earlier in the Bain stream, e.g., . According to The Washington Times., September 09, 1920, FINAL EDITION, Page 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-09-09/ed-... the Mischa Violin described there would be 19 in October 1920 (when he gave a recital at Carnegie Hall). Thanks, swanq.
Mischa Violin (1899–1984), Russian violinist. www.imdb.com/name/nm2138580/

New-York tribune., March 11, 1917, Image 28 (calendar box at right center) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-03-11/ed-... announces a recital by MIscha Violin and has a photo at top left. The Washington times., September 09, 1920, FINAL EDITION, Page 6, column 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-09-09/ed-... Has a piece titled "Strange Fate Lead Violinist to U.S." which is about Mischa Violin: "Cotton Broker in Brazil Hears Young Lad Play and Befriends Him. The Goddess of Fate plays queer pranks in the musical world. In our story she intertwined the destinies of a young Russian violinist and a New York cotton broker, and, capriciously enough, set the stage for them in a South American city. Thus it was that, in 1916. Benjamin Adler, who was in Brazil on a mission to introduce cotton there when that city was suffering a cotton famine, met Mischa Violin quite by chance in a music store, and began a conversation that eventually resulted in Mr. Adler's assuming the managership of the young Russian violinist. Mr. Adler recognized the boy's great talent after a single hearing, and decided to launch him as a concert artist in North America. All of which explains the fact that Mischa is to give his first Carnegie Hall recital on October 3 under the management of Benjamin Adler and that he is to have as his accompanist Mr. Adler's brother, Josef. While Fate may be said to have been instrumental In Mr. Adler's "discovery'' of the young violinist, it is equally true that Mlscha had blazed his own trail from the time that he began to stutfy at the age of six with his father in his native city, Odessa. Mischa Violin -- the coincidence of the boy's name and profession may be another of Fate's caprices -- played a concert in Odessa at the age of seven, and attracted the notice of Alexander Fiedmann, the Berlin pedagogue, who sent for him later and accepted him as a pupil in the Stern Conservatory. There his talent was commented upon by Adoff Brodaky, Gustav Hollonder, Artur Nlkisch, Godowsky, Safonoff, Leopold Schmitt, Oscar Bie, and other celebrities. At thirteen he graduated with the highest honors, receiving the gold medal. On Sept. 20. 1913 -- the boy was twelve years old at the time -- we find him giving a concert in Berlin with the Philharmonic Orchestra and playing the Tschaikowsky Concerto, the Spohr No. 7 and the Symphonle Espagnole. The following year found him on the books of the Wolff Bureau in Germany, and with the Vert Concert Agency in England. In June 1914, he played at a charity concert in Marlborough Hall, London, and at Buckingham Palace. He gave two recitals in London, and fulfilled a number of engagements in Belfast, Dublin and Glasgow."
A 1930 brochure for the Radio City Music Hall names Mischa Violin as an Associate Conductor. See archive.org/details/radiocitytheatre00roth (final page with text)
Mischa Elman! ....famous violinist!

Violin is his real name, having no particular significance in Russian. The Russian word for violin is "skripka"." See also www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/42232332014/

Somewhat strange to come across this (and the other) photo of Charles Lindbergh among this latest posting of circa-1920 Bain Collection photos, as Charles Lindbergh wouldn't even begin flight training (as a civilian) until April 1922. This is evidence of someone not knowing their history, posting photographs.

There does seem to be a date discrepancy, which is not totally unexpected in the Bain News Photo collection. In general, dates found on the negatives can mean one of several things: they sometimes indicate when the photos were taken, but they can also refer to a later time, such as the date the photo was added to the Bain photo stock, or, sent out to subscribers of the Bain News photo service. In this case, however, the date range for the negatives, which we are loading in sequence by negative number, seems too early. It may be that Bain sometimes inserted a more recent negative in an earlier range or reused a negative number, though it seems unlikely that he would have had reason to file a photo of Charles Lindbergh much before 1922. We have at least one photo of Lindbergh that shows him ca. 1923: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b09833 -- certainly a youthful face there! (I'll note that we have an even more youthful depiction, showing him as a child in a sailor suit, just barely visible, leaning against his father at the opening of the 60th Congress, in which his father served: Bring up the tiff file and look towards the rear rows in the center of this photo: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3c29715.) We'll adjust the estimated date in the description and continue to ponder some of the mysteries of Bain's negative numbering practices.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/barbara_loc] Often the larger date discrepancies are in photos high in the secondary numerical sequence (the number after the dash). This one has an A added, which is also a clue.  More commonly the discrepancies happen from numbers in the teens, maybe 12 and up.
Perhaps the negatives were stored in catalog drawers by the primary number to the left of the dash.  In cases where that series didn't fill the drawer, later pictures could have been added at the back of the drawer to fill them and avoid getting new cabinets, especially if there were only a relatively small number of glass negatives left in the collection at the time they started the practice?

United States Army Air Service pioneering aviator, Lt. Charles B. Austin (1891-1928), sitting atop a modified license-built de Havilland DH-4 aircraft. The photo was taken at France Field in the Panama Canal Zone (PCZ) (see linked photo from the SDASM below regarding the location). Given the date on the photo ("10/9/20") and the modifications to the aircraft (in the form of the faired-over front cockpit, which now held an additional fuel tank), this photo was likely taken as part of coverage of his aborted attempted solo air mail flight from France Field, Panama Canal Zone (PCZ) to Washington, D.C., in October 1920. See: Charles Bernard Austin (1891-1928) - Arlington National Cemetery Website "The Aborted 1920 Airmail Flight," by Robert J. Karrer, Jr., The Canal Zone Philatelist, Vol. 31, No. 4, Fourth Quarter 1995. "Army Air Flight from Panama to Washington," Army and Navy Journal, Vol. LVII, No. 49, Pages 1510-11, August 7, 1920 "The Canal Zone - U.S. First Air Dispatch," Scott's Monthly Journal, Vol. I, No. 10, Page 5, December 1920 The San Diego Air & Space Museum (SDASM) Archives on the Flickr Commons, features a collection of photos belonging to Charles B. Austin taken and collected during his time based at France Field in the Panama Canal Zone (PCZ). See: Flickr Commons - San Diego Air & Space Museum (SDASM) Archives - Lt. Charles Austin Special Collection Here is a photo of Austin from that collection: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/8068518643/] Also, among the photos in the SDASM's Austin Special Collection is a photo of President-elect, then- Senator Warren G. Harding visiting France Field, on November 27, 1920. Note, Harding's traveling party and military officers are photographed in front of same type of (if not the very same) hangar and building depicted in the Bain Collection photo of Lt. Austin and his aircraft above. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/8068516406/]

Cleveland Indians' catcher Steve O'Neil photographed at Ebbets Field during the 1920 World Series. Note the black mourning band on the left sleeve of O'Neill's uniform. The black arm band on the Indians' uniforms was worn in memory of former teammate Ray Chapman (1891-1920), who died earlier in the 1920 baseball season in August after being struck in the head by a pitch thrown by Yankees' pitcher Carl Mays during a game at the Polo Grounds. Chapman remains the only player to die as a result of an in-game injury suffered during a Major League Baseball game. Reverend Clemme Ellis White, Superintendent of the West Side Gospel Mission, New York, s. www.cityvision.edu/courses/coursefiles/301/leftmark.pdf S. also photo in the Evening star. [volume], October 10, 1920, Image 63 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-10-10/ed-...

Her New York Times Obit, "CLEMME WHITE, 87, A WOMAN MINISTER" , January 12, 1960, notes that she was ordained as a Protestant minister on September 30, 1920. timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/01/12/10517458... See also: "One person who was very instrumental in the founding and stabilization of the International Union of Gospel Missions was Clemme Ellis White. At the age of 17, she moved from her family’s farm, upstate along the Hudson River, and made New York City her home. She went to teach school and study for a medical career. Clemme Ellis became friends with Sidney and Emma Whittemore and soon started preaching the gospel one night a week at the Door of Hope Mission. While doing this, she heard the voice of God, gave up her plans for a medical career, and took charge of the West Side Gospel Mission in Manhattan’s Theater District. She conducted open-air street meetings and preached the gospel in the mission’s chapel services, all at a time when most young girls were steered away from that kind of Christian service. One night, in a street meeting, her speaking attracted the attention of Harry C. White, a salesman who had strayed from God. He followed Clemme back to the mission. He made a commitment to Christ and eventually became the assistant superintendent of the mission. Somewhere along the way, he married Clemme. Clemme Ellis White was elected secretary of the IUGM in 1919 and served as the only woman on the executive committee for thirty years. Even though there was an elected president of the association, some would argue that Clemme functioned as the first executive director. One early association president commented that her office became the center of information regarding leadership vacancies, volunteer opportunities, new mission start-ups, and mission problems. She served the IUGM longer than any other person, and many believe her tact and wisdom during the early years saved the association from major problems and possibly failure. www.jericho-road.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/2014-Volu...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert "Friedrich Ebert (German pronunciation: [ˈeːbɐt]; 4 February 1871 – 28 February 1925) was a German politician of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD) and the first President of Germany from 1919 until his death in office in 1925."

Before he became the first President of the Weimar Republic, the Social Democrat Friedrich Ebert was the head (Vorsitzender) of the Rat der Volksbeauftragten (Council of the People's Deputies) that ruled Germany between the November Revolution 1918 until the next elected government took over on February 13, 1919; from December 29, this council called itself Reichsregierung (Reich's Government). 

So this image was taken between Nov. 10-Dec. 28, 1918. It's ironic that the photographer, H. Noack, still advertises that he used to be the photographer for the Imperial Court (Hofphotograph).

This sculpture looks very similar to "Tigre portant un paon à ses petits" by Auguste Nicolas Cain. also called "Tigresse portant un paon à ses petits." There's a copy in Newport, RI. and another in Paris, France at Les Tuileries But perhaps the most likely one is in Central Park. See www.nycgovparks.org/parks/central-park/monuments/1547 "Cast at the F. Bardienne Foundry in Paris, Tigress and Cubs was presented in 1867 to the Board of Commissioners of Central Park by twelve New York citizens, including artist and inventor Samuel F. B. Morse (1791–1872). The piece was placed in a wooded area on a rock outcropping near the lake. In 1934, it was relocated to the Central Park Zoo, and after the 1988 renovation of the zoo, it took its current position in a protected setting between the Intelligence Garden and the Tropical Zone."
The location near the lake is marked by 23 in this 1871 map of Central Park Here's a crop with the location (number 23) at left center.
Wow! Thanks for outlining what looks like a good theory. We'll make a note in our records that the sculpture may be located in Central Park.

This photo was published in the [Philadelphia] Evening Public Ledger., September 27, 1920, NIGHT EXTRA, Image 26. She was sponsor of the steamship Nora, launched at the New York Shipbuilding yard the previous Saturday. The Nora is number 257 in the list of ships built by New York Shipbuilding at newyorkship.org/ships/. The Library of Congress has a picture of her under construction: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b39171 The Nora became the F.W. Abrams. See www.aukevisser.nl/inter/id108.htm "Oil tanker (Grace Steamship Co., Inc.), 13,000 grt, 98000 barrels. Named for daughter of J.P. Grace." Lillius Margarita Kent , born 1910, was the daughter of Lillius Juanita Kent, whose maiden name was Grace. See www.geni.com/people/Lillius-Kent/6000000024277262686 Nora, also born 1910, would be www.geni.com/people/Nora-Grace/6000000017251484418 and Lillius and Nora would have been cousins. Nora's father and Lillius' mother were siblings.

There's an interesting difference in the spelling of Miss Kent's first name. Early records show her as "Lillius," spelled the same as her mother. Later records and articles show her as "Lilias." She apparently married James Knott in January 1933. See: New York Times - January 11, 1933 - LILIAS KENT WED TO JAMES KNOTT; Granddaughter of the Late W. R. Grace Becomes Bride in Church Ceremony. She'd later marry Frederick Moseley Jr. See: New York Times - March 11, 1989 - Obituary - Frederick Moseley Jr., 75, Former Banker "He is survived by his wife, the former Lilias Kent Knott; three sons. . ."

Here's more on the June 11, 1942 sinking of SS F.W. Abrams (ex - SS Nora). It seems due to poor weather and navigation, she entered a minefield laid by the US Navy approximately 10 miles south of Hatteras Inlet, and struck a mine resulting in her demise. Her wreck rests 80 feet below the Atlantic Ocean, and is a popular dive destination. See: Dive Hatteras - F.W. Abrams

Link of the Evening public ledger., September 27, 1920, NIGHT EXTRA, Image 26, cited by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] above: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1920-09-27/ed-... From www.aukevisser.nl/inter/id108.htm: "The tanker Nora, named after Nora Grace, daughter of Joseph P. Grace, president of the William R. Grace Steamship Company, was launched at the north yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation September 18 (1920). The sponsor was eleven-year-old Lilias Kent, niece of President Grace." (which confirms the statements of [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] )

She was then a niece of Joseph Peter Grace Sr. (June 9, 1872 – July 15, 1950) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Peter_Grace_Sr.) and a granddaughter of William Russell Grace (May 10, 1832 – March 21, 1904), former Mayor of New York City (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Russell_Grace).

Wonderful photo. Two veterans of the American Civil War, flying together over the Gettysburg battlefield they fought upon and against each other, 73 years after the conflict ended. Our surviving veterans of the Second World War are almost at the same point in time. 

I noticed Mr. William H. Jackson's name is provided in the caption with the photo, but not the name of the other veteran. It would seem that has been lost somewhere in the shuffle. Does the Library of Congress have a record of the other veteran's name?

Some minutia concerning the photo. These veterans are flying in the rear starboard side of the passenger cabin of a Boeing 247D airliner, belonging to Pennsylvania Central Airlines (PCA).
This is nothing short of amazing.
Poignant moment captured here.  To think they experienced the American Civil War, and lived to see the Spanish-American, WWI and on the verge of WWII.
Pretty darn cool.
"War. War never changes"

See digitalcommons.unf.edu/historical_architecture_main/3409/ Old Jackson Theatre, Woodbine GA. "Tom Bruce set up his grocery/residence on this site in 1927; it is unclear whether he built it or if it was already there. Clarence Jackson bought the property and built the theater there. Early shows in the theatre were black and white silent movies. The seats were backless benches built up gallery style. There was no public restroom. In the 1950’s regular fold-up seats were installed and modern films were shown on the weekend. Cokes, candy and popcorn could be purchased in Mr. Jackson’s store next door." The picture at the link above (dated in 2009), has a sign on the building reading "Future home of Crooked River Cultural Heritage Productions." However, that name doesn't yield anything much related to Woodbine on a Google search, except jazznart.org/story-telling-2017 -- associated with a Jackie Wade.

This is probably her (auto-translated from Danish): Valborg Kirkegaard Born: 7-5-1889 in Sundby, Copenhagen Death: 4-9-1975 Gravsted: Vor Frelsers Kirkegård - Kbh Biography Valborg Olivia Kirkegaard was the daughter of sneaker Johan Edvard Kirkegaard and wife Marie Vilhelmine Østergaard. She debuted at the Red Kro Theater at the age of 17 and later appeared in the Danish provinces, cabaret in Norway and Sweden and in Tivoli Varieté and in the Winter Palace. She was married to actor and director of the artist agency "Folk Scene" Axel Svensson. They appeared in audiences including in 5 seasons in Vennelyst revues and on varieteer like "Sky & Kolja", which they called for a song they were touring with all over the country. Has participated in the following 4 revues: Charlottenlund-Revyen 1918 Odense Folketeater 1917 Tivoli 1913 1914 1915 1916 1916 1918 Vennelyst Theater Aarhus 1913 1914 1919 1920 Has participated in the following 1 stupid [Sic] movie: Peder Thordskjold (1910) danskefilm.dk/skuespiller.php?id=8248 Danish film, Peder Tordenskjold (1910) da.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peder_Tordenskjold_(film) Some photos from Vennelyst Theater productions: mona-wwwbloggercom.blogspot.com/2014/06/teaterprogrammer-... see also www.danskfilmogteater.dk/skuespillere/K/valborg_kirkegaar... Sara Louisa MacCormack Algeo (1876-1953), suffragist www.findagrave.com/memorial/107442794/sara-louisa-algeo

In September, 1920, Sara MacCormack Algeo (Mrs. James W. Algeo) announced that she was running for the Republican nomination for state senator from Providence, Rhode Island. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-09-17/ed-... "Algeo, Sara M. (Sara MacCormack), 1876- The youngest of five children, Sara Louise (A.B., Boston University, 1899; A.M., Brown University, 1911) was born in Cohasset, Mass., to John and Sarah Clements MacCormack. She taught at Cranston High School in Rhode Island from 1899 until her marriage in 1907 to James Walker Algeo. She joined the Rhode Island League of Working Women's Clubs; was active with the College Equal Suffrage League in Rhode Island, the Rhode Island Woman Suffrage Association (which she chaired), and the Providence League of Women Voters; and represented the National American Woman Suffrage Association at the 1920 congress of the International Suffrage Alliance at Geneva. The author of The Story of a Sub-Pioneer, an account of the Rhode Island suffragist movement published in 1925, she is listed in Woman's Who's Who of America, 1914-1915." snaccooperative.org/ark:/99166/w6wm48kj Her book: www.baumanrarebooks.com/rare-books/algeo-sara-m/story-of-... Her grave: "Sara Louisa MacCormack Algeo BIRTH13 Jun 1876 Cohasset, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, USA DEATH1953 (aged 76–77) Barrington, Bristol County, Rhode Island, USA BURIAL Woodside Cemetery Cohasset, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, USA" www.findagrave.com/memorial/107442794/sara-louisa-algeo

According to the Bulgarian wikipedia entry, this is Hristo Ivanov Popov (1862-1933). Translation by Google: "Hristo Popov Bulgarian politician Born 1862 Stoyakovo, Ottoman Empire He died 1933 (71 years) Bulgaria Politics Party Liberal Party (Radoslavists) Beliefs Liberalism Hristo Ivanov Popov is a Bulgarian politician, a Liberal Party actor, Minister of Justice in the second and third governments of Vasil Radoslavov, who ruled Bulgaria from 1913 to 1918, a member of the Supreme Macedonian Committee. Biography Hristo Popov was born in 1862 in the Georgiev village of Stoyakovo, then in the Ottoman Empire. He graduated from high school in Plovdiv and law at the Moscow University. He returned to the Ottoman Empire and worked as a school principal in Ohrid. Emigrated to Free Bulgaria and in 1889 he became a judge at the Rousse District Court. Since 1892 he has been a lawyer in Plovdiv. [1] At the V Macedonian Congress in the summer of 1898 he was elected member of the VMC but left at the end of the same year. From 1913 to 1918 he was a Member of the Parliament and Minister of Justice. [2] In this capacity, he was sentenced to life imprisonment by the Third State Court in March 1923, and the following year he was amnestyed."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walther_von_Lüttwitz Von Hulsen might be en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernhard_von_Hülsen or his older brother Walter. Picture of Bernhard at prussianmachine.com/korps/huelsen_bernhard.htm has similar ears, but that's hardly definitive for brothers.

The caption printed on what was presumably a postcard relates the photo to a "gegenrevolution" in March 1920. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kapp_Putsch "The Kapp Putsch, also known as the Kapp-Lüttwitz Putsch after its leaders Wolfgang Kapp and Walther von Lüttwitz, was an attempted coup on 13 March 1920 which aimed to undo the German Revolution of 1918–1919, overthrow the Weimar Republic and establish a right-wing autocratic government in its place. It was supported by parts of the Reichswehr (military) and other conservative, nationalist and monarchist factions." www.axishistory.com/axis-nations/36-germany/germany-freik... connects Freikorps Hülsen ( a paramilitary group founded by Bernhard Hülsen) with the Kapp Putsch.

Bulgarian minister of war (1915-1918). According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Bulgaria): Kalin Naidenov (1865–1925) Sometimes referred to as Kalin Naydenov, s. e.g. forum.valka.cz/topic/view/71031/Naydenov-Kalin This (or a very similar) photo ran in the Detroiter Abend-Post., October 22, 1916, FOURTH SECTION, Page 26 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn96076572/1916-10-22/ed-...
see also

His Bulgarian wikipedia entry: bg.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD_%D0%... Translation by Google: "Kalin Naydenov Bulgarian military worker Born 18 February 1865 Shiroka Laka, Ottoman Empire He died April 16, 1925 (60 years) Sofia, Bulgaria Kalin Georgiev Naydenov is a Bulgarian officer (lieutenant general) and politician. Biography He was born in Shiroka Luka with his father Georgi Kalinov Naydenov and mother Stoyka Peeva Naydenova. His father was wealthy, as well as a great patriot - participated in the revolutionary committee, where they were preparing for a nationwide uprising. He graduated from secondary school in Plovdiv, then in 1883-84 graduated the Military School in Sofia (1885). In it he demonstrates great opportunities in mathematics, and hence goes to the artillery. He started his military service in Plovdiv. In 1885 the unification of Bulgaria was declared. Naydenov is the commander of the first artillery regiment in the Serbian-Bulgarian War, participates in the battles at Slivnitsa and injured at the peak of Tri Ushi. After the war began to write actively, focusing on military themes. In 1888, he passed an examination and went to study at a military academy in Turin (Italy), which ended in 1891. In 1892, he sent him to Germany at the Krupp factories and then in France and England to familiarizes himself with the production of artillery equipment. According to his construction, there are 15-cm nuts. Based on this knowledge and skills, many European countries have sought the services of the Consultant General. After his return to Bulgaria in 1894, Kalin Naydenov taught at the Military School and occupied various positions - commander of the Batteries (1894 - 1895), head of the Sofia Artillery Arsenal (1895-1899), head of the Technical Department of the Artillery inspection (1901-1908). Naydenov participated in the Balkan Wars as Assistant Head of Artillery at the Headquarters of the Army. According to some military historians such as Dimitar Azmanov, Kalin Naydenov contributes to the widespread use of artillery in the battle against the Ottoman Empire. Balkan wars (1912 - 1913) During the Balkan War (1912 - 1913) he was assistant chief of artillery at the Army Headquarters. Between 1913 and 1915 he was an Artillery Inspector. On February 14, 1914, he was promoted to Major General. At the beginning of the First World War in 1915 he was appointed Minister of Defense and remained in this post until June 21, 1918. For his participation in the war, he was awarded with the Ottoman Medjidge I degree, the Liakat golden order (December 17, 1916), the Merit Merit Medal (1917) and the Imtyaz gold medal, the Ottoman Empire (1917) 1] In 1918, General Naydenov was fired from the army, and in 1923 he was sentenced by the Third State Court to 15 years in prison. He was amused in 1924 and became a professor of artillery at the Military School. He writes several scientific papers and articles. Author of dozens of articles in the Military Journal, Military Announcements and Fatherland, textbooks and monographs. Lieutenant-General Kalin Naydenov was killed in the Communist attack at the St. Nedelya Church on April 16, 1925"

Ibrahim Hakki Pasha (Turkish: İbrahim Hakkı Paşa, 1862–1918) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibrahim_Hakki_Pasha The Turkish and the German wikipedia entry indicates that he was Ambassador to Germany from 1915 to 1918. Ahmet Nesimi Sayman or Ahmed Nesimi Bey (1876 - 1958) tr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmet_Nesimi_Sayman He was Minister of of Trade and Acriculture (1914-1917) and of Foreign Affairs (1917-1918), s. also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Ottoman_Empire) and books.google.com/books?id=VKVSHjjUT2UC&pg=PA116&l... Another photo is in twitter.com/stephanearmenew/status/576796289385500672

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] : It looks as though İbrahim Hakkı Paşa is at right seated and Ahmet Nesimi Sayman is standing at left.  Do you agree?

Since İbrahim Hakkı Paşa died in 1918, the photo is no later than 1918.

Both men get mentioned in www.tbmm.gov.tr/tutanaklar/TUTANAK/MECMEB/mmbd01ic04c001/... (dated 1911) which is about a "Second Inquiry." and in www.turkiyatjournal.com/Makaleler/2129154376_14.pdf But both are too long for Google Translate! millicumhuriyet.com/2013/02/26/meshur-turk-masonlari-ve-m... suggests they were both masons. İbrahim Hakkı Paşa was definitely at Brest-Litowsk [en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk] in 1917-1918. A photo with him looking similar is at www.granger.com/results.asp?image=0128213&itemw=4&... According to page 233 of "Turkey Before and After Ataturk: Internal and External Affairs," these two men both signed the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk in March 1918. Given the blackletter script, it seems likely that the photo was taken in Germany, while İbrahim Hakkı Paşa was ambassador -- between 1915 and July 1918, when he died. The spelling of "Pascha" also seems German.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] 1. Sure! 2. The mark "NPG" stands for "Neue Photographische Gesellschaft", a German company. (de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neue_Photographische_Gesellschaft) There are other photographs of this company of Turkish people in this stream as well. I do not think that one can deduce that this photographs were taken in Germany.
There is other mark on the right, "Phot. Bufa, B(erlin)", which means "Bild- und Filmamt", a propaganda department of the German army. de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bild-_und_Filmamt

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] :
So this could have been taken at Brest-Litovsk by an NPG photographer.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Maybe. But NPG worked apparently as a copy-house and publisher, I rather doubt that they had their own photographers. I suspect that most of the templates of Turkish people came from Turkish sources in order to be distributed by NPG (and Bufa) in Germany, because Turkey was an ally of Germany in WWI.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05]  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Thank you for the additional information on Pascha and Bey. We'll adjust the date range to 1915 - 1918.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_of_Greece "Paul (Greek: Παύλος, Pávlos; 14 December 1901 – 6 March 1964) was King of Greece from 1947 until his death in 1964."

The date 10/28/1920 is written on the negative. The picture was clearly taken earlier, since in 1920, he would have been 19. In late October 1920, Paul, who was in exile with his father, would have been in the news because of discussions of succession. His brother Alexander [en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_of_Greece] who was king, was bitten by a monkey with rabies and died on 10/25/1920. "The sudden death of the sovereign led to questions over the monarchy's survival and contributed to the fall of the Venizelist regime. After a general election and a referendum, Constantine I (Paul's father) was restored to the throne."

www.birchington-pc.gov.uk/news/granddaughter-of-queen-vic... has a picture of Paul, his parents, and siblings. More pictures of the family at www.pinterest.co.uk/brookeb499/king-constantine-i-family/ This Bain photo seems to be a crop of www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/292100725814726732/ BUT according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_of_Greece, which shows the same family group, the boy this crop focuses on is Alexander and not Paul. Since Paul was the youngest brother, I think this picture is of Alexander.

This aircraft is a US Army Air Service (USAAS) Fokker D.VII, likely one of among well-over 100 of the type surrendered/given to the United States by Germany, pursuant to the 1918 Armistice. Given the "Winged 1" insignia, it belongs to the 1st Aero Squadron, which was based at Mitchel Field on Long Island from 1919 to 1940. Various online sources suggest the Fokker is being put through a loop over Long Island by distinguished aviator Lt. Eugene Hoy Barksdale (1896-1926). Unfortunately, I've yet to discover sufficient information to confirm the location and pilot.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/25695066@N00] Thank you for the aircraft and squadron identification—we'll add both to the record.

From Boston Magazine here's some of the backstory on Houdini's jump. When Houdini Jumped Off the Harvard Bridge by Madeline Bilis "What better way to promote an upcoming performance in Boston than to be locked up in chains and take a 30-foot plunge into the Charles River? "That’s exactly what Harry Houdini did on April 30, 1908. (Spoiler alert: He lives!) Before two weeks of performing at Keith’s Theater on Washington Street, the master of the “Impossible Possible” decided to take his talent of escaping from handcuffs and chains a step further by doing so underwater. "Houdini stood at the edge of the Harvard Bridge—commonly referred to as the Mass. Ave. Bridge—and was shackled by a Boston patrolman. His hands were handcuffed behind his back and chained to a collar around his neck. According to a Boston Globe article chronicling the feat, a signal was tooted from a towboat, and Houdini went overboard into the chilly waters below. "'There is always the possibility that I will be unable to free myself, as one never can tell what will happen to a lock,' Houdini told the newspaper. 'However, I am a good swimmer, have confidence in myself, and I hope to perform this feat successfully.' "The Globe estimated some 20,000 spectators gathered to see Houdini’s leap, including the mayors of Boston and Cambridge. They waited 40 seconds for the magician to resurface, which he did with the shackles in his hands. "Born Nina Constance Shawe (1889-1975) in Coonoor, India, in 1889, but grew up and was educated in England. When she became an actress in the theater, she took the name Gypsy O’Brien. "In December 1914, Gypsy sailed as a member of a British theater troop from Liverpool to New York. She appeared in To-Night’s the Night, a musical comedy that ran at Shubert’s Theatre from December 1914 into the spring of 1915. "For the next two years, she worked steadily in musicals on the New York stage. Gypsy entered films in 1916 with an Olga Petrova vehicle, The Soul Market (1916). Later that year, Gypsy appeared with Earle Williams in The Scarlet Runner, a 12-chapter series that related the adventures of Christopher Race (Williams) and his high-powered automobile, The Scarlet Runner. "Her screen work was sparse through the 1910s. In 1920, she was given the lead with Lionel Barrymore in The Master Mind (1920), a First National melodrama. "Gypsy’s remaining film roles were small. She was with Pauline Starke in Salvation Nell (1921) and The Young Diana (1922) with Marion Davies. She spent two months with her family in England in the summer of 1922. After working again with Davies in Little Old New York (1923), Gypsy devoted more time to her stage work. "While touring in Is Zat So? through California in the mid-1920s, Gypsy met George Blankenhorn, a steel plant engineer. They were married in 1928. Gypsy retired from show business. "The Blankenhorns lived quietly in Pasadena. George died in December 1956. Gypsy passed away on September 2, 1975. Gypsy’s only living relative, Mrs. Lillian Dewdney of London, England, announced her death." – CLOSE-UPS AND LONG-SHOTS by Michael G. Ankerich

Photo of James M. Cox, Democratic Party nominee for President in 1920, leading a parade on 42nd Street (Manhattan) from west to east, as he approaches the intersection of Madison Avenue and 42nd. The photographer's perspective is from the north side of the intersection on Madison Avenue, looking toward 42nd St. to the southwest and Cox as he approaches the intersection. The Union Carbon and Carbide Building Union Carbide and Carbon Building (built in 1913, demolished in 2001) serves as the backdrop for the scene. Here's a rough approximation of the view today, via Google Street View: www.google.com/maps/@40.7528447,-73.9792767,3a,75y,270h,9... [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]

Trudy Ederle apparently had five brothers and sisters. The only sister for whom I've found a name is her older sister, Margaret (Meg). Meg both encouraged her as a youngster to take swimming seriously and was part of the support team for her successful swim of the English Channel. Meg is in a photo dated August 7, 1826 at www.gettyimages.com/event/oct-gertrude-ederle-born-527821... To me, the match is possible but not definite.

Hiram Sibley Bicket (1881-1941) and Edward Morris, Jr. (1893-1972), of the meatpacking company, Morris & Company. Morris's father founded the company, his son would rise to heading the company after his father's passing in 1913. Bicket and Morris are standing in front of a Curtiss Oriole aircraft. See: Wikipedia - Morris & Company This same photo is featured in The National Provisioner, Vol. 63, No. 12, September 18, 1920, Page 149, with the caption, "Morris and Hiram Bicket ready to fly to New York after the convention." The "convention" referred to is the "Fifteenth Annual Convention of the Institute of American Meat Packers," held in Atlantic City, New Jersey, from September 13-15, 1920.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street_bombing "The Wall Street bombing occurred at 12:01 pm on September 16, 1920, in the Financial District of Manhattan, New York City. The blast killed 30 people immediately, and another eight died later of wounds sustained in the blast. There were 143 seriously injured, and the total number of injured was in the hundreds. The bombing was never solved, although investigators and historians believe the Wall Street bombing was carried out by Galleanists (Italian anarchists), a group responsible for a series of bombings the previous year. The attack was related to postwar social unrest, labor struggles, and anti-capitalist agitation in the United States."

This seems to be: "Charles Albert Cannon (Nov. 29, 1892 - April 2, 1971) A textile marketing genius, Charles Cannon would build a nationally dominant brand through advertising and packaging innovations for Cannon Mills." www.historync.org/laureate%20-%20Charles%20Cannon.htm "Charles Albert Cannon (November 29, 1892 – April 2, 1971) was born, lived and died in Concord, North Carolina. the son of James William Cannon and president of the Cannon Mills Company from the 1920s to the 1960s." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Albert_Cannon There is a film about his career on this page that has some shots of him as a young man. charlescannonfilm.com/about-charles-a-cannon/

I doubt that this is Charles Albert Cannon (Nov. 29, 1892 - April 2, 1971). In the film it's this man: www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05/39945173620/ but the shape of the ear is different. The evening world., August 21, 1920, Final Edition, Image 1, col. 6 reported that Ellen Beach Yaw was to be married to a man called Charles Cannon. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1920-08-21/ed-... According to other sources her husband was Franklin Delaney Cannon (1882 - 1953), a pianist and teacher from New York, s. e.g. www.findagrave.com/memorial/125207914/franklin-delaney-ca... The Los Angeles Herald, Number 6, 8 November 1920 printed a photo of him. cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19201108.2.135 Could be this man though IMO.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Put it down as a subject for further research.  Charles Cannon was only 28 in 1920, so it would be useful to find younger pictures of him.  One argument that this is not him is that he didn't come into prominence until 1921, when his father died and he took over the business.

Thanks for searching [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] and  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05]. I was able to locate a copy of this photo Bain gave us (the scan was made from a negative). On the back they wrote that he was to wed Ellen Beach Yaw. I also saw articles that said she married Franklin Delaney Cannon but the put the wedding at the same day so all I can figure is that Charles was a nickname or else he performed professionally under one of the names (maybe there was another Franklin/Frank Cannon that he didn't want to be confused with). I did find an article saying they were divorcing in 1935. Apparently Cannon's work kept him on the east coast while her work kept her in the west. (That article used the name Franklin)

"Mrs. D.J. Mahoney" is Helen Harding Cox Mahoney (1896-1921), daughter of former Ohio governor and 1920 Democratic Party presidential nominee, James M. Cox. She is shaking hands with aviator Howard Rinehart, one of the Dayton-Wright RB-1 co-designers. (As mentioned in the note above, he is the "R" in the "RB-1" model designation. The "B" is co-designer Milton C. Baumann.) Helen Cox was married to Daniel J. Mahoney (1889-1963), general manager for one of the newspapers owned by her father. Her father's business would eventually become today's Cox Communications. Sadly, she would pass away the following year at the age of 25, after suffering from a bout of pneumonia. See: www.findagrave.com/memorial/145206723/helen-harding-mahoney www.findagrave.com/memorial/179129316/daniel-j-mahoney

1920's tournament in France was the final Gordon Bennett Aviation Trophy race, a competition that was held six times, and began in 1909. "The Gordon Bennett Aviation Trophy was an international airplane racing trophy awarded by James Gordon Bennett Jr., the American owner and publisher of the New York Herald newspaper. The trophy is one of three Gordon Bennett awards: Bennett was also the sponsor of an automobile race and a ballooning competition." The pictured plane competed, but did not finish the race. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Bennett_Trophy_(aeroplanes) See also

This is the Dayton-Wright RB-1 Racer, built to compete in the 1920 Gordon Bennett Cup (like the Verville-Packard R-1 Racer also in the most recent posting of Bain photos). It is still extant as an exhibit at the Henry Ford Museum. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton-Wright_Racer

The Richmond palladium and sun-telegram., August 13, 1920 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86058226/1920-08-13/ed-... reports that the U.S. was awarded 5 German warships after WWI and that they would visit several ports before being destroyed. They included the battleship Ostfriesland and the cruiser Frankfort. Albuquerque morning journal., August 24, 1920, CITY EDITION, page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84031081/1920-08-24/ed-... has a picture (very poorly reproduced) that could be of this scene. It says that four of the five ships were tied up in the Hudson River, New York. The ships in the picture are thus likely to be the cruiser Frankfort (or Frankfurt) and destroyers C-102, V-43, and S-132. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS_Frankfurt

The United States Army and Navy Journal and Gazette of the Regular and Volunteer Forces, Volume 57, Part 2 books.google.com/books?id=oEG17z92iSsC&pg=PA1535&... describes the operation of bringing the vessels across the Atlantic. The Ostfriesland came under her own steam and towed the Frankfurt. The others were towed by the U.S. minesweepers Falcon, Redwing, and Rail.
See also The Ogden standard-examiner., July 15, 1920, LAST EDITION, Image 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1920-07-15/ed-...

The same photo as in the Albuquerque morning journal., August 24, 1920 in a (little) better quality is in The Chickasha daily express., August 19, 1920, Page PAGE FIVE, Image 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86090528/1920-08-19/ed-...

This Bain photo pictures (left to right) the German large torpedo boats V 43, G 102 and S 132 and the American minesweeper USS Redwing (AM-48), s. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:German_torpedo_boats_in_US_LOC... The V 43 was a V 25-class torpedo boat en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_ocean-going_torpedo_boats_an...: V 43 - launched 27 Jan 1915 - completed 28 May 1915 - Interned, Scapa Flow, 22 Nov 1918; attempted scuttling on 21 Jun 1919 failed and ship recovered; to USA, 1920; sunk as air bombing target off Cape Henry, 15 Jul 1921. S 132 see: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/39773555110/ G 102 see: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/41581672881/

S132 was a German destroyer ceded to the U.S. after WWI. The U.S> minesweeper Redwing had towed on of the three ceded destroyers across the Atlantic. The destroyers had been scuttled by the Germans in Scapa Flow and raised by the British. See

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_ocean-going_torpedo_boats_an...: S 132 - Launched 19 May 1917 - Completed 2 Oct 1917 - Interned, Scapa Flow, 22 Nov 1918; beached while attempting to scuttle, 21 Jun 1919; to USA, 1920; sunk as gunnery target by USS Delaware (BB-28) and destroyer USS Herbert (DD-160) off Cape Henry, 15 Jul 1921. www.rcuniverse.com/magazine/NewProduct.cfm?product_id=3879 shows a model kit of the plane and states, "Texas Millionaire S.E.J. Cox sponsored the design of this aircraft, along with the Cactus Kitten 1, to enter in the 1920 Gordon Bennett Cup Race. Before crashing and destroying the aircraft in France, pilot Roland Rohlfs hand painted “Texas Wildcat” in black in the fuselage."

New-York tribune., September 12, 1920, Page 3, Image 61 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-09-12/ed-... is a full-page piece on the American entries for the Gordon Bennett race to be held in France on September 27, 1920.
At bottom is secondary caption indicating Mr. & Mrs. Cox.

suggests that Cox, an oil magnate, is the man reaching towards his wife. The pilot, Roland Rohlfs, is presumably the guy in the helmet. The Rock Island Argus and Daily Union., September 06, 1920, Image 6, bottom of column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn92053933/1920-09-06/ed-... indicates that Cox and his wife both commissioned planes as entries in the Gordon Bennett race.

According to a NYT article, Rohlfs crashed and destroyed the plane during a warmup flight for the Gordon Bennett Cup competition, on September 26, 1920 in Etampes, France. Clarence Coombs was the backup pilot for the flight. However, it doesn't appear that either Cox plane competed in the race. www.nytimes.com/1920/09/27/archives/rohlfs-hurt-in-trial-... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Bennett_Trophy_(aeroplanes) see also

S.E.J. (Seymour Ernest Jacobson) Cox (15 April 1884 - 20 December 1971), turned out to be a bit of a dubious character - to put it mildly. A Google search turns up various frauds and schemes perpetrated by Cox, including this depiction in a most recently published book. See: Kings of Big Spring: God, Oil, and One Family's Search for the American Dream, by Bryan Mealer, Flatiron Books, 2018, Pages 40-43: S.E.J. (short for Seymour Ernest Jacobson) Cox was, in the words of the Federal Trade Commission, "the most seductive and unreliable promoter in America." Before arriving in Texas, he'd created dozens of companies from Michigan to New York City, peddling everything from "miracle" carburetors to wallpaper and virility pills. But an oil boom presented untold opportunity. In 1917, Cox had moved to Houston and began selling interests in three separate ventures, passing himself off as a savvy dealmaker. . . . . . . The rest of General Oil's wells turned up dry, and soon Big Spring got smart to Alphabet Cox. After his company went bust, Cox was indicted for mail fraud. He managed to escape the first set of charges, but not a second. A promotion scheme with Dr. Frederick A. Cook, who dubiously claimed to have been the first explorer to reach the North Pole, finally landed Cox in prison.

Information at Ancestry.com indicates Mrs. Cox's full name was Nellie Edith McDonald Cox (1885-1971). See: search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?gl=ROOT_CATEGORY&... As does S.E.J. Cox's profile in Men of the South - A Work for the Newspaper Reference Library, Daniel Decatur Moore, et al., editors, Southern Biographical Association, 1922, Pages 659 and 672. . . . On April 25th, 1907, he married Miss Nellie McDonald, and one son, Seymour E.J. Cox, Jr., a bright lad of 11 years, has blessed the union. Like all men of affairs, Seymour E.J. Cox, Sr., has a hobby, aeronautics. He, with Mrs. Cox, toured the oil fields of Texas in their Curtis [sic] and [de] Havilland aeroplanes. He is a member of the Aero Club of America, Aero Club of Texas, Texas Auto Club and Country Club of Houston, the town he calls home. Mr. Cox and his wife each entered an airplane in the international flight flown in France in September, 1920, in competition for the Gordon Bennett cup. . . .

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Howat "Alexander McWhirter "Alex" Howat (1876–1945) was a Scottish-born American coal miner and trade union leader. Howat is best remembered as the chief opponent of the Kansas Court of Industrial Relations in the early 1920s and as the leader of a radical rank-and-file revolt against the officialdom of the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) in 1923." Also described in www.marxists.org/archive/cannon/works/1921/howat.htm "the Kansas miners were among the most militant sectors of the American labor movement. Their leader Alexander Howat had been imprisoned in 1919 for refusing to call off a local strike, and frequent wildcats finally caused the state to set up a special Industrial Court in 1920. "

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_C._Adamson "William Charles Adamson (August 13, 1854 – January 3, 1929) was a U.S. Representative from Georgia and a Judge for the United States Customs Court." bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=A000051 "ADAMSON, William Charles, a Representative from Georgia; born in Bowdon, Carroll County, Ga., August 13, 1854; attended the common schools; was graduated from Bowdon College in 1874; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1876 and commenced practice in Carrollton, Carroll County, Ga.; judge of the city court of Carrollton 1885-1889; attorney for the city of Carrollton for a number of years; delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1892; elected as a Democrat to the Fifty-fifth and to the ten succeeding Congresses and served from March 4, 1897, until December 18, 1917, when he resigned; chairman, Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce (Sixty-second through Sixty-fifth Congresses); appointed on December 17, 1917, a member of the Board of United States General Appraisers (now the United States Customs Court) and served until January 20, 1928, when he resigned; resumed the practice of law in Carrollton, Ga.; died while on a visit in New York City, January 3, 1929; interment in City Cemetery, Carrollton, Ga."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asta_Nielsen "Asta Nielsen (11 September 1881 – 24 May 1972) was a Danish silent film actress who was one of the most popular leading ladies of the 1910s and one of the first international movie stars.[1] Seventy of Nielsen's 74 films were made in Germany where she was known simply as Die Asta (The Asta). Noted for her large dark eyes, mask-like face and boyish figure, Nielsen most often portrayed strong-willed passionate women trapped by tragic circumstances. Due to the erotic nature of her performances, Nielsen's films were heavily censored in the United States and her work remained relatively obscure to American audiences."

There are several clips of Asta Nielsen on YouTube, including this 3 minute clip from The Abyss. I would say it's very sensual by 1910 standards. The Abyss also apparently appears in it's entirety [36 min].

A little more on Astra (Asta Sofie Amalie Nielsen [Geburtsname]; Asta Gad [Ehename]) – from FemBio:
"For late bloomers of every stripe there is no better role model than the astonishingly multi-talented Asta Nielsen: She began her literary career at 65. Danish Nobel Laureate in Literature Johannes V. Jensen wrote of her memoirs: 'If you weren't a great actress, then you would have become a great author.' In fact, she continued writing – stories, articles for newspapers and, later, a series of radio lectures entitled Growing Old: A New Life. At the same time, she produced some successful work as a visual artist: 'I created a new form of painting, not with brush and paint, but with colorful fabric from which I assemble people and animals, landscapes and flowers.' "She directed her first film at 86. After a film about her life did not meet with her approval, she set to work on the project herself. The result was a work of art. At the beginning of the 1960’s, 83-year-old Asta Nielsen had to come to terms with the most severe blow of her life: Her daughter Jesta committed suicide following the death of her husband. "Finally, at 88 years of age, Asta Nielsen married her third husband, Christian Theede, an art dealer 18 years her junior and the great love of her life. The two enjoyed their travels together so much that they decided to leave their fortune to a foundation to fund trips for the elderly. 'It was so lovely to travel,' said Asta Nielsen, 'we want to make that possible for others now too.'"
And more biographies: wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/asta-nielsen-2/ www.kortermand.dk/tshirt/asta_uk.htm and a Flickr album of portraits, posters, etc. from the Film Museum

This is William Robinow (1894?-1996) [i.e. William Robyn] (pronounced ROW-BINE), birth name (in Latvia) William Rubin, also known as Willie Robyn and toured at the time of his first auditions (trials) with Victor and Emerson in 1918 as Wolf Scarpioff. [1] Robyn was a tenor singer who toured the vaudeville circuit and made hundreds of recordings. He recorded first for Emerson, but then for Columbia, Pathe, Okeh, Brunswick, Victor and approximately 50 other labels. This is William Robinow (1894?-1996) [i.e. William Robyn] (pronounced ROW-BINE), birth name (in Latvia) William Rubin, also known as Willie Robyn and toured at the time of his first auditions (trials) with Victor and Emerson in 1918 as Wolf Scarpioff. [1] Robyn was a tenor singer who toured the vaudeville circuit and made hundreds of recordings. He recorded first for Emerson, but then for Columbia, Pathe, Okeh, Brunswick, Victor and approximately 50 other labels. These three young ladies were pictured in the Pensacola Journal., August 20, 1920, Page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87062268/1920-08-20/ed-... in a very similar photo. "Here are the prettiest feet and ankles in New York City. Hundreds of girls entered the contest held in Grand Central Palace. And it was only after hours of thoughtful and stern consideration that the Judges were able to pick the' winners. Miss Consuelo Furman (left) won the first prize of $500, which is in the bag she is holding. Second prize, Miss Virginia Wynn (center). Third prize, Miss Irene Jones (right). The observing judges also discovered, they announce, that pretty feet and ankles do not necessarily go with a pretty face."

The caption with a similar photo in an advertisement for Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue, 46th to 47th Sts., New York. -- The Coolest Place to Shop in New York City -- in the Evening World, August 17, 1920, Wall St. - Final Edition, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1920-08-17/ed-... "At left. Miss Consuelo Furman, a music student of New York City, winner of first prize, $500.00 in gold. Centre, Miss Virginia Wynn, of Amherst, Mass., second prize, pair of gold slippers. Of all theatrical entries her feet and ankles were considered the most beautiful. Through having been discovered in this contest, Miss Wynn has been given a leading part in the forthcoming production, 'The Rose Girl.' At right, Miss Irene Jones, third prize winner, with a pair of silver slippers. Miss Jones recently won a beauty contest. The Judging Committee was composed of famous artists, including C. D. Williams, Jack Sheridan, Arnold Genthe, Lejaren a' Hiller, George Howe, J. Knowles Hare, George P. Thomas and Miss Marian Oliphant."

"Nominee Will Not Leave Train During Brief Stay in the Pennsylvania Station Governor Cox will be in this city for an hour to-day on his way to New Haven. The earthquake was on June 21, 1920, and this is downtown Inglewood, California.

The Sun and the New York herald., July 04, 1920, Section 5 Rotographic Section, Image 48 printed a photo of nearly the same location with the caption: "First picture to reach New York of the recent earthquake near Los Angeles. Front of the Hotel Inglewood. Six shocks were felt and more than $100,000 damage done." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030273/1920-07-04/ed-... See also twitter.com/SeismoSue/status/795614646535274496. According to that, this building was on the west side of Commercial Street, now the South La Brea Avenue.
Thanks  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/army_arch] and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], we'll add this information to our catalog record.

The earthquake was on June 21, 1920 in Inglewood, California, and this is a view of Dr Mary S Ertl's monument in the Inglewood Park Cemetery.. From what I understand this monument was restored and moved over to Forest Lawn and is inside a mausoleum. Dr Ertl was the first woman to practice medicine in Los Angeles.
See www.inglewoodparkcemetery.com/fine_arts/ertl.html and www.findagrave.com/memorial/21059/mary-s.-ertl

There's a reversed date in the lower left corner of the image. It is either 1/30/27 or 7/30/27. If it's January, then this could be from either the funeral of Emperor Taisho (died Dec. 25, 1926) or the installation of Emperor Showa (Hirohito). I found a New York Herald Tribune article from Jan. 23, 1927 (p. B4) which listed Inoue and Togo amongst people at the at Showa's installation ceremony.

According to the[New York] Sun. October 05, 1913, SEVENTH SECTION, Page 4, Image 60, Column 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1913-10-05/ed-... "Count and Countess Emilio del Sera were among the recent arrivals from Europe They were married in London last July. The Countess was before her second marriage Mrs. Eben Wright." This matches the suggested identification above. The [New York] Sun., December 21, 1913, SEVENTH SECTION, Image 50 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1913-12-21/ed-... has a compatible portrait of the countess.
books.google.com/books?id=cC0EAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA134&a... indicates that she was married to Eben Wright on May 20, 1891. They had two daughters and her husband died in 1908.

NYT of Nov 15, 1932 www.nytimes.com/1932/11/15/archives/chihuahua-divorce-obt... indicates that the count divorced Leta Constance Wright del Sera of New York. It indicates that she was 51 when they married in 1913. He was 29. So she was born about 1862. This NT article indicates why she was in the news in 1920. He and her husband were investigated by Italian authorities to ascertain if her daughter Anna Wright was being kept prisoner against her will. They were exonerated. I suspect this picture is from much earlier than the 1920 timeframe of many nearby Bain photos.

Evening Star. August 04, 1920, Page 8, column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-08-04/ed-... reports that Anna Wright was mentally ill and was confined to her parents' home in Florence because she refused to wear clothes.

Thanks for all your work  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05]. In the biographical file in our reading room I found several photos of Countess Del Sera that confirm you found the right person. We'll update the catalog record.

Osaka appears to have 808 bridges. See www.city.osaka.lg.jp/kensetsu/cmsfiles/contents/0000042/4... www.geocaching.com/geocache/GC312HN_noninbashi-pedestrian... suggests that it (or more likely its replacement) is a "huge pedestrian bridge constructed under the highway." One of the comments says "What a huge intersection with the longest pedestrian bridge ever" and has a photo of the location in 2017. www.city.osaka.lg.jp/contents/wdu020/enjoy/en/overview/pd... has a map that shows the location of today's Nonin Bridge. It's roughly in the center of the map, crossing the Higashi-Yokobori river. The intersection is of Matsuyamachi Avenue and Chuo-odori Street. It's also a highway intersection. www.cujucr.com/downloads/pdf_6_2008/Koichi Kana.pdf has a historical discussion of the Higashi-Yokobori river (actually a canal) and describes 1912-1926 (Taisho period) as the period of Dai Osaka “Great Osaka” with modern architecture coming to line the riversides.

We now think it is the Noninbashi (農人橋) bridge, ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%BE%B2%E4%BA%BA%E6%A9%8B. The Wikipedia page says that the previous version was built in 1926 and if you look at the top of our photo you'll see the date 11/29/26 in reverse. The "no" would translate to farming or agriculture, the "nin" to people, and "bashi" is bridge.

"Baker Art Gallery was the most prominent photography studio in Columbus, Ohio for over eighty years. The studio was founded by Lorenzo Marvin Baker. He began his photography career in the 1860s. His studio was located in different locations on High Street in downtown Columbus. In 1886 the studio became known as Bakers Art Gallery or Baker Art Gallery and his son Duane joined the business. Four generations of the Baker family operated the studio until 1955. After the studio closed Mrs. Lorenzo P. Baker donated a large collection of negatives and photographs from the studio to the Ohio Historical Society." www.ohiohistory.org/learn/collections/history/history-blo...

Baron Wakatsuki Reijirō (若槻 禮次郎, 21 March 1866 – 20 November 1949) was a Japanese politician and the 25th and 28th Prime Minister of Japan. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wakatsuki_Reijir%C5%8D

NYT of November 10, 1926 indicates that there was a political scandal involving Premier Wakatsuki at the time.  The former Kenseikai Communications Minister (Minoura) who had been charged with graft, had filed perjury charges against Wakatsuki.   Supporters of Minoura had delivered a ceremonial dagger to Wakatsuki's residence (implying he should commit hara-kiri).  According to the Wikipedia article linked in the previous comment, Wakatsuki continued as Premier until April 1927, when forced to resign because of a financial crisis.

Interview for oral history project from 1979, text and audio file. "HELEN MOSES CASSIDY After leaving Hilo for Honolulu in 1919, Helen graduated from Punahou in 1924 and studied for a year and a half at the University of Hawaii. Then she worked for some time in the registrar’s office at the University before her marriage to Charles Cassidy. She returned to the Big Island to live at Waimea in 1937. Her daughter, Loujean Vannatta, is in Honolulu with her children, Lauren and Charles. Her son, John E. Cassidy and his wife, Rae, live in Walnut Creek, CA. also living there is her other granddaughter, Lisa Cassidy. Oil painting is Helen’s hobby and she is a staunch supporter of the Waimea Arts Council. Recently she became interested in writing lyrics for her musical efforts. She calls a “pleasant diversion” rather than actual song writing. The first Cassidy to attend Punahou was Eliza Emily Emmes (1877-93) whose father was a shipwright in Honolulu harbor. She married John Cassidy. Three generations since have attended Punahou, with Charles W. Vannatta III in the eighth grade in 1980-81." www.outriggercanoeclubsports.com/occ-archives/oral-histor...

Elizabeth Callender Stevens (ca. 1870-ca. 1963) She was married to her second cousin Richard Stevens (1868-1919) on November 11, 1893, in Hoboken, New Jersey. (www.nyhistory.org/exhibit/mrs-richard-stevens-ca-1870-ca-...) Richard Stevens, her first husband, was the son of Edwin Augustus Stevens (July 28, 1795 – August 8, 1868), an American engineer, inventor, and entrepreneur who left a bequest that was used to establish the Stevens Institute of Technology. In October 1925, she married Josef Forman, s. fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2011/New%20York%20Evening%20P..., first column. In June 1920, she sailed to Europe on the liner France, together with her daughter Caroline. Another passenger was Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr, who sailed to join Mr. and Mrs. W. K. Vanderbilt Sr. (depicted in a photo nearby) in France , s. timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/06/25/11818363...

The baby is Gloria Caruso, born Dec. 18, 1919. See
Thank you for the identification. We'll add Gloria's name to the catalog record.

The baby is Gloria Caruso, born Dec. 18, 1919. Behind Caruso is his wife, the former Dorothy Park Benjamin. Sitting beside his father is presumably one of the sons from an earlier relationaship with singer Ada Giachetti: Rodolfo " Fofo" Marcellino Giuseppe Caruso, born in 1898 or Enrico Caruso, Jr. born in 1904. See For Rodolfo (no later than 1917), see

Some other copies of this photograph online have captions indicating that the son here is Rodolfo and the two children his. However, there is no indication in obituaries of Caruso that he has any grandchildren. See, for example, NYT of August 2, 1921 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801E7DA173EEE3AB... Nor do any grandchildren get mentioned in the discussions of how his estate was to be divided. Rodolfo served in the Italian army in WWI and seems to have been based in Italy. I think the photo looks more like Enrico, Jr. (Mimmi) who was in the U.S. in the summer of 1920 prior to attending Culver Military Academy. See Enrico Caruso - His Life and Death. By Dorothy Caruso books.google.com/books?id=L9N8CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT162&l... My best guess for the other woman and two blond children Is that she is Katherine Ward Benjamin (nee Doremus). Her husband was Park Benjamin, Jr., Dorothy's brother. NYT of June 27, 1923 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940CE4DA1339E433A... reports that Katherine was filing for divorce and had two children, Betty, 6 and Park Benjamin Jr. 7. I have no confirming photographic evidence, but do know that Mrs. Park Benjamin was at the house the Carusos had rented for the summer in June 1920, when there was a burglary. See Keowee Courier., June 16, 1920, page 3, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026912/1920-06-16/ed-... describing a re-enactment of the evening when the burglary was discovered.
Sadly, these photos were taken soon before Caruso's precipitous decline in health.

Following up the NPG logo at bottom right, I find www.npg-steglitz.de/NPG Katalog.htm. Neue Photographische Gesellschaft See www.doaks.org/research/library-archives/dumbarton-oaks-ar... "The Neue Photographische Gesellschaft (NPG) was the first and for many years the biggest factory for real photographic bromide printing and the production of real photograph postcards. Arthur Schwarz (1862–1944) founded the company in 1894 in Berlin-Schöneberg, and there were later subsidiary companies in various cities including London, New York, Paris, Vienna, Brussels, and Milan. The company closed in 1921, although the NPG trademark and the postcard department were acquired by E. A. Schwerdtfeger, located first in Berlin and then in Dresden." More (in German) at de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neue_Photographische_Gesellschaft
