Related to event reported in earlyradiohistory.us/1920melb.htm [from Telephony, July 10, 1920, page 19] "As a further test of the efficiency of wireless telephony Dame Nellie Melba was invited to entertain Europe by wireless. The concert was staged at the Marconi station at Chelmsford in Essex, a 2,800 meter wave length being used. Dame Melba arranged to sing in three languages--English French and Italian. Amateur wireless telephone operators throughout Europe were advised to "listen-in" and the trans-Atlantic liners fitted with the Marconi receiving sets were specially advised of the concert time. These included the Olympic, the Bardic, the Megantic, Caronia, Bosworth and other popular boats." This photo is used in A Concise History of British Radio, 1922-2002 by Sean Street books.google.com/books?id=y7jo0IcUZeoC&pg=PA11&lp... which indicates that the event was on June 15, 1920.

New York, July 21.—Archbishop Daniel Mannix, of Ireland and Australia, did not reach Brush Stadium yesterday until the second game of the double-header. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/kristi_loc] -- The newspaper article I found and cited in a comment with the older woman's photo indicates that Marie is the first name of the mother (the widow of Louis Bustanoby) and the daughter sailing on the Dante Alighieri is actually called Cecile. I have found no evidence that Marie and Louis had more than two children -- a daughter Cecile who was a musician, and a son Andre. I'm wondering whether Bain may have got the daughter's name wrong. I haven't found convincing evidence that this is Cecile, but it seems possible. The Washington times., September 20, 1919, FINAL EDITION, page 1, bottom of column 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1919-09-20/ed-... states that she has a daughter, Cecile, and a son Andre. New-York tribune., July 04, 1920, Page 2, image 34 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-07-04/ed-... has a photo of Cecile -- compatible with the photo here but not an absolutely convincing match. Since it mentions that she will be studying music in Rome, this is the daughter who sailed on the Dante Alighieri. == for convenience, I'm copying in the quotation I has added earlier to the photo of the mother == The New-York Tribune., July 13, 1920, Page 11, column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-07-13/ed-... says: "Mrs. Bustanoby Sails Mrs. Marie D. Bustanoby, widow of the late Louis D. Bustanoby, and her daughter, Miss Cecile D. Bustanoby, sailed on the Dante Alighieri for Rome and Constantinople. Their first stop will be at Naples, whence Miss Bustanoby will go to Rome and finish her music studies. Her mother will go to Constantinople to visit with her parents until they return to America in the early part of October."

Louis Bustanoby was the proprietor of the Cafe Des Beaux Arts according to lostwomynsspace.blogspot.com/2011/05/cafe-des-beaux-arts-... However, www.theamericanmenu.com/2012/02/the-cafe-martin.html has different details. "French-born restaurateur Andre Bustanoby began his career at the Restaurant Martin on University Place in 1895, before moving on to Delmonico’s, and eventually joining his brothers Louis and Jacques to open the Cafe des Beaux Arts on 40th Street, near Bryant Park. The Cafe des Beaux Arts closed during the first week of 1912, at which time Louis opened the Taverne Louis in the basement of the Flat Iron Building. By 1915, Andre Bustanoby owned a restaurant at Broadway and 60th Street, perhaps operating in the space previously occupied by Louis Martin. The [New York] Sun., March 23, 1912, page 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1912-03-23/ed-... has an advertisement in which Louis Bustanoby announces that he has resumed control of the Cafe des Beaux Arts and continues to run Taverne Louis in the Flatiron building. This may resolve the apparent conflict between the two sources cited above.
Trow Directory, Printing and Bookbinding Company, 1919 associates Marie D. Bustanoby with the Cafe des Beaux Arts Co. See books.google.com/books?id=EJw0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA184&l...
www.aheadworld.org/2017/03/16/woodlawn-cemetery-louis-bus... indicates that Louis Bustanoby died in 1917.

The New-York Tribune., July 13, 1920, Page 11, column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-07-13/ed-... says: "Mrs. Bustanoby Sails Mrs. Marie D. Bustanoby, widow of the late Louis D. Bustanoby, and her daughter, Miss Cecile D. Bustanoby, sailed on the Dante Alighieri for Rome and Constantinople. Their first stop will be at Naples, whence Miss Bustanoby will go to Rome and finish her music studies. Her mother will go to Constantinople to visit with her parents until they return to America in the early part of October."
Thank you for providing additional information about the subject and linking to Chronicling America!

 [https://www.flickr.com/photos/dpirmann], unfortunately we don't have any digitized, but when people come to the reading room, I often pull out a set of stereographs copyrighted in 1871 that show cats posed in pots. So yes, cat photos go back a long time.

The locomotive is presumably named after en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Haupt "Herman Haupt (Philadelphia, March 26, 1817 – Jersey City, December 14, 1905) was an American civil engineer and railroad construction engineer and executive. A Union Army General, he played a key role in the American Civil War, during which he revolutionized U.S. military transportation, particularly the use of railroads."

General Herman Haupt, standing atop the bank at right in boots and long coat, surveying repair work by a work crew near Bull Run, Virginia in 1863. They are using the locomotive HERMAN L. HAUPT. Haupt had a major influence on organizing Federal repair work on the railroads.

1920 America's Cup en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resolute_(yacht) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shamrock_IV en.wikipedia.org/wiki/America%27s_Cup

Resolute was designed and built by Nathanel Herreshoff to the Universal Rule (which he concocted) to defend the Cup in 1914. Unpleasantness intervened, and racing was not resumed until 1920. Sir Thomas Lipton challenged with the Charles Nicholson designed Shamrock IV. Resolute won, 3-2.
see

Their informal introduction took place in the yards of the Morse Dry Dock and Repair Company while the defender and the British challenger were occupying slips in the largest floating drydock in the world.

Launch of destroyer USS HOPKINS (Destroyer No. 249) on June 26, 1920 at New York Shipbuilding, Camden, New Jersey, across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. HOPKINS was commissioned on March 21, 1921. Converted to a destroyer minesweeper in 1940 (redesignated DMS 13), she decommissioned on Dec. 21, 1945 at Norfolk, Virginia and was sold for scrap in November 1946. A more detailed history is at www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/da...

The date on the side is 30 Jun 1920, just four days after her launch. The pattern of portholes is consistent with the later photos of USS Hopkins, DD-249.

The phonograph is an Aeolian-Vocalion model, and the record she is holding is from the same label. "Vocalion (pronounced "vo-CAL-yun") was founded in 1916 by the Aeolian Piano Company of New York City, which introduced a retail line of phonographs at the same time. " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vocalion_Records The "Aeolian-Vocalion" label appeared in the U.S. in late 1917, first as a 1200, then 12000 series of vertical-cut records. Unlike the records then available, they were a reddish-brown colour, and the company's promotional material stressed the "red records". After it became legal, the company launched a line of lateral records in a 14000 series in 1919. The "Aeolian" was dropped from the unwieldy name in 1920 and the label became "Vocalion". www.capsnews.org/barrbru.htm

Thanks for connecting this image to another in the collections,  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton] , and thanks for the fascinating information about the phonograph shown in the image,  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] ! We will update the record.

Building demolished, but pagoda saved. The story so far: "Jimmy Woo’s restaurant opened in 1950 and was sold twice before closing in 2008. It continued to operate as a bar — renamed the Red Parrot Nightclub and Lounge — before shutting all operations in 2012. The iconic pagoda was removed in 2014 from the roof of the former Woo's Pagoda restaurant in Eau Claire. A crane was used to move the structure onto a flatbed truck. It’s currently being stored at Banbury Place." [See photo] www.leadertelegram.com/News/Front-Page/2017/03/26/A-place... "Staff are asking the community to help locate an indoor facility for the structure so that it can be repaired. They said an indoor facility needs to be located by May 15 [2017], otherwise the pagoda will be dismantled and removed from Banbury Place. Staff said efforts will shift to preserving the smaller top section of the pagoda, which has already been detached from the main structure. www.wqow.com/story/35188851/2017/04/Wednesday/eau-claire-... "The pagoda structure from the former Woo's Pagoda restaurant has been sitting outside Banbury Place since 2014 after the Chippewa Valley Museum rescued the structure when the restaurant was being torn down. The museum had until May 15 to find a new storage location, and now, according to Nick White, with The Local Lounge and Live in Eau Claire, Chippewa Valley Door Company has agreed to house the pagoda while Live in Eau Claire restores it. White said the plan is to have it permanently located at The Local Lounge." www.wqow.com/story/35374678/2017/05/Monday/latest-eau-cla...

Arthur G. Hickman (June 13, 1886 – January 16, 1930) was a drummer, pianist, and bandleader of one of the first big bands. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Hickman

This is most likely from the band's New York run in 1920, before their return to San Francisco in the Fall of 1920. Some more detailed info about the players: "For the 1919 New York trip, the band consisted of Steve Douglas, violin, Walt Roesner, trumpet, Fred Kaufmann, trombone, Clyde Doerr, alto and baritone saxes, oboe, and clarinet, Bert Ralton, soprano and tenor saxes and clarinet, Frank Ellis, piano, Vic King, tenor banjo, Ben Black, plectrum banjo, Bela Spiller, string bass, and Art Hickman, drums, piano, and slide whistle. [...] two of his key sidemen defected at the close of the 1920 Follies. Bert Ralton and Vic King became popular freelancers, ultimately teaming up to form what became first the New York-Havana Band, playing a long engagement (originally offered to Hickman) at the Gran Casino de la Playa in Havana, then the Savoy-Havana Band at London's Savoy Hotel. Hickman replaced Ralton with Walter Beban, an ex-Marine from San Francisco who had played in vaudeville before the War, sometimes touring with Sophie Tucker." www.gracyk.com/hickman.shtml
Thank you Richard, beachcomber, and Art for the extensive information on Art Hickman's Orchestra. We'll add the appropriate information to the catalog record.

This could be the popular singer, Arthur Hall (1888-1951), but I can't find any pictures of him. "Arthur Hall (his real name was Adolph J. Hahl) was born in New York on May 12 of 1888. His first recordings were on 1912 as member of the Manhattan Quartet (Manhattan Quartet / Manhattan Quartett), with whom he stayed until 1929. During the World War I, Adolph J. Hahl changed his name to Arthur Hall on 1917 due to the anti-german hysteria, & started recording as solo artist as well. Among the many recordings he did on as solo artist, Hall cut "Yes, We Have No Bananas!" on 1923 for Black Swan under the pseudonym of Howard Lewis, which went also issued on the Olympic label. Hall also worked for other labels (both as solo artist & part of vocal groups ranging from duets to quartets as well as providing vocal refrains for jazz & dance band records) such as the Plaza group (Banner, Domino (as either Allen Craig or Cliff Stewart), Regal, Oriole (as Charles Nelson), etc.), Emerson, Everybodys, the Grey Gull group (Grey Gull, Madison, Supreme, Radiex, Globe, Amco, etc.) (the Grey Gull company used masters from the NYRL group, Emerson & other companies until it opened his own studio on 1926), the NYRL/New York Recording Laboratories group (Paramount, Puritan, Broadway, Puretone, etc.), the Pathé Frères Phonograph Co. (Pathé Actuelle, Actuelle, Perfect (3), Davega, etc.), The Arto Company (which also included Bell (4), Cleartone Records (2) & many others), the Bell Record Corporation (which included Bell (4)), Gennett & Edison, just to mention several of these. From 1924, Arthur Hall began recording several duets with tenor John Ryan (14), beginning with "Hawaiian Nithningale" (matrix 9863 - recorded on November 21 of 1924) / "I'm Someone Who's No One To You" (matrix 9832 - recorded on November 7 of 1924) (released on Edison Diamond Disc 51473), which brought the beginning of a long series of recordings by Hall & Ryan, both under their own names & several pseudonyms (for example, The Harmony Brothers). Hall & Ryan were also augmented by Ed Smalle when they recorded also as The Frolickers for Edison. One year later, Hall joined the vocal group That Singing Four, which also gave way to the National Male Quartet on 1926. His final Edison Diamond disc was "Sweet Elaine" (matrix E-18188 - recorded on January 24 of 1928), which was issued on Edison Diamonc Disc 52235 on 1928. Arthur Hall died during March of 1951 in New York. " www.discogs.com/artist/2885603-Arthur-Hall-2 books.google.com/books?id=-FOSAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA939&l... adp.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/talent/detail/40739/Hall_A... cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?nq=1&query_type...
Thank you—we can indicate that Arthur Hall is possibly pictured.

Henry S. Priest, a former Federal Judge, was candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States senator of Missouri in 1920. Evening star. [volume], June 06, 1920, Page 22, col. 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-06-06/ed-... One of his opponents was Breckinridge Long, who was nominated. But Selden P. Spencer won reelection. This man and the chief counsel for the Waters-Pierce Oil Company are probably the same.

From the Federal Judicial Center: "Priest, Henry Samuel Born February 7, 1853, in Ralls County, MO Died July 9, 1930, in St. Louis, MO Federal Judicial Service: Judge, U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri Nominated by Grover Cleveland on August 6, 1894, to a seat vacated by Amos M. Thayer. Confirmed by the Senate on August 9, 1894, and received commission on August 9, 1894. Service terminated on May 23, 1895, due to resignation. Education: Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, A.B., 1872 Read law, 1873 Professional Career: Private practice, Moberly, Missouri, 1873-1880 City attorney, Moberly, Missouri Attorney, Missouri Pacific and Wabash Railroads, St. Louis Missouri, 1881-1894 Private practice, St. Louis, Missouri, 1895- Candidate for U.S. Senate from Missouri, 1920 Candidate for governor, Missouri, 1924" www.fjc.gov/node/1386601 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Samuel_Priest

George Tryon Harding II (June 12, 1843 – November 19, 1928), known as Tryon Harding (often misspelled Tyron), was an American physician and businessman who is best known as the father of Warren G. Harding, the 29th President of the United States. He was the first presidential father to outlive his son, and the second presidential father (after Nathaniel Fillmore) to live through his son's presidency. In his biography of Warren G. Harding, Charles L. Mee describes Tryon Harding as "a small, idle, shiftless, impractical, lazy, daydreaming, catnapping fellow whose eye was always on the main chance". en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Tryon_Harding

"First opened in 1956, this unique roadside fast-food joint was originally located at Cumberland Head corners near Gus' Red Hots. A year later the entire restaurant was disassembled and moved piece by piece down North Margaret Street where it was re-built opposite the present day McDonald's. The Julep quickly became a North Country favorite and featured michigans, it's very own signature drink, and car hop service for patrons. In 1970, the iconic Plattsburgh eatery was even featured in a national magazine focusing on fast food restaurants. The Orange Julep was demolished around 1979 and only the empty parking lot where the restaurant once stood remains today." en-gb.facebook.com/GusRedHots/

Barbara Maurel's frequent accompanist in this period was Frederick Bristol. see books.google.com/books?id=gNtFAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA4-PA49&am... March, 1920 recital. books.google.com/books?id=jEFFAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA350&d... April, 1922 books.google.com/books?id=N-U6AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA23-PA10&a... This is the probable grandson of the more famous Frederick E. Bristol: "Frederick E. [Eliud] Bristol (4 Nov. 1839, Brookfield, Conn. - 1932 N.Y. City) was a celebrated American voice teacher who operated a private studios in Boston and New York City during the second half of the 19th century and early 20th century." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Bristol One of Frederick E.'s children was Frederick Anthony Bristol. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=150234560 Frederick A. Bristol died in New York in 1940 at the age of 76, according to his obituary being the son of "a noted vocal teacher" leaving a son, Frederick "a well known concert pianist." and another son Edward. fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=ht... www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=bristo...; New York Times ran an obituary for another Frederick Bristol in April, 1974, "a pianist who headed the piano and voice department at Briarcliff College and later at Caldwell College", at age 77. Survived by a brother, Edward. timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1974/04/16/14880559... The evidence is circumstantial, but this is probably Frederick E. Bristol, 2nd. Alice Miriam, soprano. She died in 1922, aged 28. The New York herald., August 13, 1922, Page 16,(photo) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1922-08-13/ed-... Evening star. [volume], July 24, 1922, Page 3, col. 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1922-07-24/ed-...

Born Alice Miriam Pinch. "Alice Miriam one of the most promising of the younger members of the Metropolitan Opera Company died iate Saturday night last in the Flower Hospital this city. Miss Miriam was operated on a week ago for appendicitis and was apparently recovering when septicemia set in and necessitated a second operation from which the singer did not rally. She died a few hours later Miss Miriam had sung two seasons with the Metropolitan and her soprano voice had attracted much favorable comment. Last season when Lucrezia Bori was indisposed Miss Miriam received her first big opportunity to sing a principal role. She was given the title role in RimskyKorsakoff's The Snow Maiden and she handled the role both vocally and histrionically with surprising skill and success obtaining without exception the entire approval of the New York critics. It is said that she had signed a three years contract with the Metropolitan Opera Company at the conclusion of her last season's contract. Miss Miriam hails from Glendale Md but studied music in Rome and Milan where she also toured. Several years ago when she returned to her native country she was engaged to tour with the late Enrico Caruso through this country and Canada. The body was taken to her father's home in Maryland where the funeral services were held on Tuesday July 25. -Musical Courier, July 27, 1922. books.google.com/books?id=N-U6AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA3-PA49&am... "Birth: Oct. 17, 1887 Newton Harvey County Kansas, USA Death: Jul. 24, 1922 Note: died at that age of 28; no marker Burial: Holy Trinity Cemetery Bowie Prince George's County Maryland, USA" www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=31260819

A similar photo is in The Guthrie daily leader., June 10, 1920, HOME, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86063952/1920-06-10/ed-... and in The Sun and the New York herald., June 13, 1920, Section 5 Rotographic Section, Image 60 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030273/1920-06-13/ed-...

Both photos were likely taken at New York Navy Yard on the day of the battleship's commissioning, 3 June 1920. The deck view is taken from the ship's fantail looking forward. Note numerous visitors on deck, including women in formal attire, as well as photographers with tripods, indicating a festive occasion, yet a great number of shipyard workers dressed for work occupy most of the topside spaces above the main deck. The ship is incomplete --  scaffolding surrounds the main top, and calibration equipment is attached to the 14-inch guns of No.4 main batter turret. TENNESSEE was officially completed and delivered to the Navy on 16 September 1920.

I think this is the Easter Crisis of 1920: "COPENHAGEN MOBS DEMAND REPUBLIC; PALACE GUARDED; Streets of the Danish Capital Filled with People at Midnight. ROUSED BY CABINET UPSET Dismissal of Premier Zahle Is Connected with Slesvig Plebiscite. GENERAL STRIKE MENACED Trade Unionists Early in the Evening Warned King Christian. COPENHAGEN, Tuesday, March 30.-- Large crowds fill the public squares throughout the city at this hour, demanding the establishment of a Danish Republic, and all streets leading to the Royal Palace are held by the police." New York Times, March 30, 1920 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9803E2D61E3AE433A... "The Easter Crisis of 1920 was a constitutional crisis and a significant event in the development of constitutional monarchy in Denmark during the Easter in March-April that year. It began with the dismissal of the elected government by the reigning monarch, King Christian X, a reserve power which was granted to him by the Danish constitution. [...] Christian dismissed the rest of the government and replaced it with a de facto conservative care-taker cabinet under Otto Liebe. The dismissal caused demonstrations and an almost revolutionary atmosphere in Denmark, and for several days the future of the monarchy seemed very much in doubt. In light of this, negotiations were opened between the king and members of the Social Democrats." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Easter_Crisis_of_1920

Dorothy Foss Brewster "Birth: May 6, 1889 Portland Cumberland County Maine, USA Death: Oct. 7, 1971 Dexter Penobscot County Maine, USA Late Senator's Widow Former Me. First Lady Dies in Dexter Mrs. Dorothy F. Brewster, 82, widow of the late United States Senator Owen Brewster, died Oct. 7 at her home at 37 Zions Hill, Dexter. She was born in Portland, May 6, 1889, the daughter of Charles S. and Cora (Macy) Foss. Following graduation from the Portland schools, she receved her Bachelor or Arts degree from Wellesley College in 1911. On April 20, 1915 she married Owen Brewster in Portland. They lived there until 1925 when her husband was elected governor of Maine and Mrs. Brewster began four years of public service as the First Lady of Maine and official hostess of the governor's mansion the Blaine House, at Augusta. In 1929, she moved to Dexter with her family." More at: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=115883313

Seems so. (though this source gives birth year as 1868): "Sigurd Berg ( July 3, 1868 at Bogø - July 11, 1921 in Copenhagen ) was a Danish politician and minister. He was the son of the leftist Christian and Maren Berg . He was educated as a journalist at Kolding Folkeblad . In 1892 he became editor-in- chief at Frederiksborg Amtsavis , where he was headed in 1895. In the years 1899-1905 he was a member of the city council in Hillerød . From 1901 to 1910 he was a member of the Folketing for the first time , and in 1905-1908 he was Minister of the Interior of the Ministry of Justice JC Christensen . Berg, like the other members of the ministry JC Christensen, had to leave as a result of the Alberti scandal . In 1910, he received a fine of 1000 kroner from the Rigsrätt for not, as the Minister of Internal Affairs, to have properly supervised the Sealand Bonding Reserve, which Alberti was chairman until September 1908. In 1918, he became a member of the Parliament and was in 1920 and 1921 Minister of the Interior of the Ministry of Neergaard II . Berg became Knight of Dannebrog in 1905 and Dannebrogsmand in 1907. He received the 2nd Command Cross in 1908. A few days before the parliamentary elections in September 1920, he got the Commander Cross of the 1st grade." da.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigurd_Berg [via Google Translate]

"J.T. Tripp" is Juan Terry Trippe, aviator and founder of Pan American Airways ("Pan Am"), one of the great (and now gone) US airlines. Trippe left Yale to train as a Naval Aviator during World War I, but the war ended before he'd have a chance to fly in combat. After the war he returned to Yale, where he graduated in 1921. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Trippe en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan_American_World_Airways His co-pilot is former Army Air Service aviator, George Willard Horne ("G. Willard Horne"), also attending Yale (Class of '21) post-war. See: archives.yalealumnimagazine.com/issues/99_05/old_yale.html books.google.com/books?id=xjM6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA944&l... Trippe and Horne flew for Yale in the collegiate aerial races at Mitchel Field, Long Island, winning the 25-mile cross-country flight race on May 7, 1920. The race is reported in The Outlook, Vol. 125, May 19, 1920, "The First Collegiate Aerial Races," Pages 103-104, where there is also a contemporaneous photo of them at the time. See: books.google.com/books?id=IQY-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA104&l... The race and competitors are further detailed in Aircraft Journal, "Collegiate Flying Competition at Mineola," Vol. VI, No. 19, May 10, 1920, Pages 5-6. books.google.com/books?id=ssg_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA54&lp... The aircraft Trippe and Horne flew in the race, wearing Army Air Service serial number A.S. 45246, is a Curtiss Jenny variant (Curtiss JN-6HG-1). See: www.joebaugher.com/usaf_serials/1908-1920.html

"Joseph-Honoré Ricard is an agricultural engineer and politician born on 3 December 1880 in Bouscat (Gironde) and died in December 1948 A graduate of the National Agronomic Institute, he works mainly on the situation of farmers, and in particular the agricultural mutual and the unionists' associations, for the Union des syndicats agricoles and the Société des agriculteurs de France . After 1914, he joined the Ministry of Agriculture where he held various positions, including the Directorate of Immigration and Agricultural Labor. In 1919, he founded the National Confederation of Agricultural Associations. Although he has no political career in the strict sense of the word, his technical skills and his knowledge of the farming community mean that he is called to government by Alexandre Millerand , in the Agriculture portfolio, in place by Georges Leygues , he occupied until January 1921. Vanitie was one of the early Universal Rule class boats (later converted to a schooner and a I-class boat) built for America's Cup racing. She was builit in 1914 at George Lawley & Son's in Neponsit and contended to defend the cup in 1914 (when the race was postponed due to war) and in 1920. Both times she finished second to Resolute. This photo is likely from her yard period at Jacob Brothers shipyard prior to the defender trials in May 1920 when the crew replaced sails and rigging damaged in a yard fire two months earlier and replaced the old deck with a lighter, laminated deck. All to no avail. The final race against Resolute was June 24, 1920. By July 6th she had been hauled out (on City Island in NY) dismasted and stripped. In happier days: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/boston_public_library/6796088752/] See also: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5764552773/]

Helen Yorke (Helen Sherman Yorke), coloratura soprano, Prima donna, with her husband Misha E. Appelbaum, editor of The Humanitarian and founder and president of the Humanitarian Cult, and director of the Musical Bureau of America. Photographed in 1920 in their home at 471 Central Park, West, New York City. "Born in Russia, Appelbaum made his fortune as a copper and metals merchant but became famous by founding The Humanitarian Cult. The Cult, which held meetings in the famed house at 266 West End Avenue [1], was a somewhat Socialist organization that fought for a variety of social causes including the fight against capital punishment, poverty, the war, and for women’s suffrage. Instead of dues or membership fees, aspiring members were directed to pay grocers’ and butchers’ bills for impoverished families." [2] [3] # Compiling additional data 09-17-17

She was the former Florence Pullman (1896–1937). A chapter about him, with a picture of her, is in "Art and Beauty in the Heartland: The Story of the Eagle's Nest Camp at Oregon, Illinois, 1898-1942" books.google.com/books?id=wXxcliaEM4gC&pg=PA93 She is described as "not just any debutante. She was the beautiful daughter of America's richest and best-known railroad manufacturer." Although Wikipedia says they had 3 children, "The Sage of Sinnissippi", a book about Frank Orren Lowden, books.google.com/books?id=P2IfAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA18 says they had a son, Pullman (born 1897), and three daughters, Florence (born 1898), Harriet Elizabeth (born 1900), and Frances Orren (born 1903). Page 23 books.google.com/books?id=P2IfAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA23 has a picture of mother and children when the youngest was an infant.

According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Pullman, she was born in 1868 (the date in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Orren_Lowden is apparently mistaken). See also www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8221 Her husband: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8497173123/

This appears be a New York City letter carrier with hat badge No. 814. The Bain publication date appears to be December 22, 1924. In an attempt to confirm/narrow the date of this photo I searched the archives of The Literary Digest for 1900-1925 without finding the issue (cover) in the mailman's sack.   I also searched Google images and eBay for Literary Digest (1900-1925) without success, although I could have missed it.   It's unclear to me what the archives represent, as they don't display the covers seen in Google images or on eBay.   I have no doubt someone will find it on their first search attempt ;)

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelwrangler] : my search attempts have come up blank too. My only observation is that the cover layout with the date top center may have come in during the Spring of 1920. See www.ebay.ca/sch/i.html?_sacat=0&_nkw=literary+digest+... for examples from January and February 1920 (without top center dates) and from June, July, and October with the same layout as the cover the postman is carrying.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], good observations on the layout and layout changes! In looking at the eBay examples in your link I noticed that virtually all of the magazine covers have a Cheshire address label obscuring part of the cover somewhere near the top of the magazine and very often it's been affixed right over The Literary Digest name.   Yet in the Bain photograph, there isn't a label -- unless it's covered by the postman's hand in the bottom left corner of the magazine, which seems unlikely given the number of covers with the Cheshire label near the top. It makes me wonder if perhaps this was a staged promotional photograph somehow on behalf of The Literary Digest. Note how all the "messy" string/twine is sort of behind the magazine, while only a single strand crosses the subject cover. I'm hoping this is an outtake while the postman blows his nose, or whatever he is doing ... ; )

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelwrangler] : I had also wondered if it was staged. I took a look at what's in the Hathi Trust archive for Literary Digest. See catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000051914 It looks as though the magazine came out in quarterly volumes and the most likely volume is volume 65. A copy of this volume has been digitized at the University of Minnesota, but it looks as though the covers weren't included when issues were bound into the volume. Some volumes from the University of Michigan do have covers, but there doesn't seem to be a copy of volume 65 from the University of Michigan in the Hathi Trust archive.
Another Bain photo taken on the same occasion reveals that the date on the issue is May 22, 1920.

Similar photo (credited to Underwood) ran in the New York Tribune, January 25, 1920 with the caption: "New Yorkers, meet your Secretary of State, Mr. Francis M. Hugo, whose candidacy for Governor of the Empire State has been formally indorsed by the Jefferson County Republican Committee. If you are not familiar with Mr. Hugo's signature look at the bottom of your auto license" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-01-25/ed-... However, he did not receive his party's nomination: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-07-29/ed-... "Francis M. Hugo (March 5, 1870, Kingston, Ontario, Canada – December 30, 1930 Manhattan, New York City) was an American politician." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Hugo

Hart-Faure; d. 23 Dec 1946), dau. of Benno Hart, of San Francisco, California, USA Died s.p.m. 16 Apr 1941 (killed in a London air raid) suc. by cousin, note served in World War II as F/O RAFVR; Assistant to Air Attach, Paris 1940 Daughter 1. Hon Susan Constance Eden (b. 5 Sep 1918), mar. (1) 19 Nov 1942 (div. 1956) Jose Diaz de Rivera, son of Jose Diaz de Rivera, of Asturias, Spain, and (2) 5 Jan 1957 Guillermo Pakenham Bridges OBE, Hon Vice-Consul in Rio Grande, Argentina (d. 1980), son of William Samuel Bridges, of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/auckland1793.htm ==================== Hon. Susan Constance Eden F, #35020, b. 5 September 1918 Hon. Susan Constance Eden was born on 5 September 1918.1 She is the daughter of Frederick Colvin George Eden, 6th Baron Auckland and Susan Livingstone Hartridge.1 She married, firstly, Jose Diaz de Rivera, son of Jose Diaz de Rivera, on 19 November 1942 at Mexico City, MexicoG.1 She and Jose Diaz de Rivera were divorced in 1956.1 She married, secondly, Guillermo Pakenham Bridges, son of William Samuel Bridges, on 5 January 1957. From 19 November 1942, her married name became Diaz de Rivera.1 From 5 January 1957, her married name became Bridges.1 She lived in 1999 at Estancia Viamonte, Rio Grande, Tierra del Fuego, ArgentinaG. www.thepeerage.com/p3502.htm#i35020 ========================= Susan Livingstone Hartridge F, #35018, d. 15 January 1966 Susan Livingstone Hartridge was the daughter of Augustus Griffin Hartridge. She married Frederick Colvin George Eden, 6th Baron Auckland, son of William Morton Eden, 5th Baron Auckland and Sybil Constance Hutton, on 2 June 1917. She and Frederick Colvin George Eden, 6th Baron Auckland were divorced in 1925 at U.S.A.G. She died on 15 January 1966. Her married name became Eden. After her marriage, Susan Livingstone Hartridge was styled as Lady Auckland on 31 July 1917. www.thepeerage.com/p3502.htm#i35018 ====================== Frederick Colvin George Eden, 6th Baron Auckland M, #35017, b. 21 February 1895, d. 16 April 1941 Frederick Colvin George Eden, 6th Baron Auckland was born on 21 February 1895. He was the son of William Morton Eden, 5th Baron Auckland and Sybil Constance Hutton. He married, firstly, Susan Livingstone Hartridge, daughter of Augustus Griffin Hartridge, on 2 June 1917. He and Susan Livingstone Hartridge were divorced in 1925 at U.S.A. He married, secondly, Constance Caroline Hart, daughter of Benno Hart, on 25 April 1939.2 He died on 16 April 1941 at age 46 at London, England, killed in an air raid. He was educated at Malvern College, Malvern, Worcestershire, England. He was educated at Camborne School of Mines, University of Exeter, Penryn, Cornwall, England He succeeded as the 6th Baron Auckland, of West Auckland, co. Durham [G.B., 1793] on 31 July 1917. He succeeded as the 6th Baron Auckland on 31 July 1917. He gained the rank of Flying Officer in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve. He held the office of Assistant to the Air Attaché to Paris in 1940. www.thepeerage.com/p3502.htm#i35017

New York Times noted the arrival aboard the Cunard Liner Imperator on March 2, 1920, Sir Ernest Glover of the British Ministry of Shipping. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06E2DA103BEE... "Sir Ernest William Glover, 1st Baronet (27 August 1864 – 21 January 1934) was an English shipowner and public servant. Glover was born in Lenton Green, County Durham, to Septimus Jonathan Glover and his wife Elizabeth Ann, the daughter of Edwin Briggs of South Shields, Durham. He was educated in Germany and at University College School, London and became a partner in the family firm, Glover Brothers, a London shipowners (Shakespear Shipping Company) and ship and insurance brokers. He married Helen Harrower Reynoldson, daughter of J. P. Reynoldson of South Shields, in South Shields in 1889. During the First World War he joined the Ministry of Shipping as Director of the Ship Management Branch. For this service he was knighted in 1918 and was created a baronet of Arkley in the parish of Barnet in the County of Hertford in the 1920 Birthday Honours." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Ernest_Glover,_1st_Baronet

She was 94 years old and lived in Ithaca. Miss Morgana was born in Buffalo, where she began her career as a child performer at the Pan-American Exposition. She studied voice in Milan with Theresa Arkel, and was then engaged as an assistant artist on Caruso's concert tours. During one of these tours, she met and married Bruno Zirato, who followed tenure as the tenor's private secretary and business manager with a distinguished career in music administration, culminating in the managing directorship of the New York Philharmonic in the 1950's. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._B._Yeats "William Butler Yeats (/ˈjeɪts/; 13 June 1865 – 28 January 1939) was an Irish poet and one of the foremost figures of 20th century literature. A pillar of both the Irish and British literary establishments, he helped to found the Abbey Theatre, and in his later years served as an Irish Senator for two terms."

Yeats arrived in New York, the start of a lecture tour of the U.S. and Canada, on January 24, 1920. In this photo, he holds a volume of William Blake, with a label from the London Library on St. James Square. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9504EED81F38E5... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Library

For Art Siegel: Yeats's 1893 edition of Blake's poetry is probably more responsible than anything else for Blake's status as a major figure in English literature. That's why the ending of W. H. Auden's poem "In Memory of W. B. Yeats" (1939) is written in the rhythm of Blake's "The Tiger." For anyone who may be interested: a photoshopped version of this image is viewable at theartpart.jonathanmorse.net/william-butler-yeats-contemp...
Here's a set of the 1893 Yeats edition of Blake's poems for sale: www.biblio.com/book/works-william-blake-poetic-symbolic-c...

John F. McGuiness, prohibition enforcement agent. He was found dead in December 1920, s. South Bend news-times., December 27, 1920, Morning Edition, Image 1, col. 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87055779/1920-12-27/ed-...

His name is spelled both as McGuiness and McGuinness in that article. Also a James Francis McGuiness, prohibition agent, died in the line of duty on December 24, 1920, presumably the same person in the newspaper article. "Federal Prohibition Agent James Francis McGuiness United States Department of the Treasury - Internal Revenue Service - Prohibition Unit, U.S. Government End of Watch: Friday, December 24, 1920 Federal Prohibition Agent McGuiness was shot and killed by unknown suspects in Bayonne, New Jersey. His body was found floating close to shore in Newark Bay, near 43rd Street. He had been shot once in the head. Agent McGuiness was survived by his wife and three children. Age: 37" www.odmp.org/officer/9001-federal-prohibition-agent-james... "Agent McGuiness [1884-1920]joined the Prohibition Unit on January 21, 1920, placing him among the first group of agents hired to enforce the National Prohibition Act. His annual salary of $2,750 was considerably higher than other new agents, but his Government service had begun in 1910. Prohibition Agent James McGuiness was killed by unknown assailants. His body was found with bullet wounds on both sides of his head on the shores of Newark Bay, NJ. No suspects were ever identified. Agent McGuiness was born in Jersey City, NJ. He was survived by his wife." www.atf.gov/our-history/fallen-agents/james-f-mcguiness
Blog entry on Prohibition HQ, with more details of Agent McGuiness' death: daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2014/02/prohibition-headqu...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hôtel_Beauharnais "The Hôtel Beauharnais is a historic hôtel particulier in the 7th arrondissement of Paris, France. " "After the French defeat in the Napoleonic Wars and the Congress of Vienna, the premises were first rented and finally purchased by Prussia under King Frederick William III in 1818 and became the seat of the Prussian legation. In 1862 Otto von Bismarck resided here, before his appointment as Minister president by King William I in September. Following the Franco-Prussian War of 1870–71, it served as the embassy of the German Empire to the French Republic." Title and description from Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division:
Miss Rose Cade--Queen of the Lemons Rose Cade, who has also been nominated Southern California's "Swat the Jinx" girl, dressed in model of large lemon pointing to calendar dated Friday, February 13, 1920. Photograph – "From Keystone View Co., Inc. of N.Y." National Photo Company Collection.
– From The Santa Fe Magazine • Volume 14 • 1919
"Miss Rose Cade, a dainty Los Angeles girl, gives the laugh to superstition. She has accepted the office of "Queen of the Lemons" at the National Orange Show held annually in San Bernardino, Cal. Miss Cade not only doesn't mind being classed with the lemons, but scorns the idea of Friday the thirteenth being unlucky. This is the date for the opening of the orange show, the directors of which this year have adopted the slogan "Swat the Jinx." When horror was expressed over the selection of the date for the annual display of California's leading crop, directors of the show explained that weather records proved there was the least likelihood of rain during the period February 13 to 23 [1920]. More than a million oranges, lemons, grapefruit and limes will be in the exhibit."
Rose Cade was a silent screen actress, known for "Greater Than Love" (1921), "Salvage" (1921) and "A City Sparrow" (1920). [1]

www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q38963498 [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/36715697780] Philip S. Smith was graduated from the Sheffield Scientific School with the Electrical Engineer degree in the class of 1907 and he married Lenore Lambert, a native of Louisville, Kentucky. He is special examiner for the United States bureau of foreign and domestic commerce and for the past year has been in South America, making observations and reports for the United States government. Prior to this he was in charge of the foreign sales department for the General Electric Company of Schenectady, New York, having charge of the South American, Canadian and Mexican trades. In applying for his present position he was chosen out of ninety-four applicants, a fact which indicates his superior ability and high standing. He is a remarkably intelligent and progressive young man and undoubtedly has before him a brilliant future.

Miriam Hostetter's (1900-1968) third husband was William "Bill" Zener Breed (d.1939).  Bill was the former president of the Western Reserve Kennel Club and he was the writer of "The Little Black Bag" column in Dog World.  Mrs. William Breed was active with the American Boxer Club who reported that
"She was later married to Mr. Galligan whom she divorced, resuming the name of Breed. "Mrs. Breed owned and bred over fifty champions at her famous Barmere Kennels [Roslyn, Long Island, NY]."
So still no first name for husband-number-four Galligan, but we did learn that she kept the name Breed, which no doubt helped with her business as a breeder.                     *      *       *       *       *       *       *       *   Fun facts:  the first Boxer was introduced to the United States in 1904, and the first Boxers were shown at Westminster dog show in 1925. Anagram for Miriam Virginia Hostetter: "Invite Him To Stir Marriage"

"Jellicoe married, at Holy Trinity church, Sloane Street on 1 July 1902, Florence Gwendoline Cayzer, daughter of the shipping magnate Sir Charles Cayzer. [...] Lord and Lady Jellicoe had a son and five daughters. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Jellicoe,_1st_Earl_Jellicoe "Florence Gwendolyn Jellicoe Born 20 Jul 1877 in Liverpool, Lancashire, England Died 12 May 1964 in Westminster, City of London, England, United Kingdom" www.wikitree.com/wiki/Cayzer-6 see also

Jellicoe and his wife took a trip round the world, starting in 1919. See Rock Island Argus., July 14, 1919, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn92053934/1919-07-14/ed-... According to The Maui news., November 14, 1919, Page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1919-11-14/ed-... Jellicoe arrived in Vancouver on the battle cruiser New Zealand. According to The Great Falls Daily Tribune., November 19, 1919, Page 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024808/1919-11-19/ed-... when in Vancouver, Lady Jellicoe received news of her mother's death. They were en route for Ottawa. The Harrisburg Telegraph., November 24, 1919, Page 20 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038411/1919-11-24/ed-... reported that Jellicoe and his wife were in Canada and would visit New York after Christmas. The Washington times., January 02, 1920, FINAL EDITION, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-01-02/ed-... reports that Lady Jellicoe had been indisposed and the journey from Ottawa to New York delayed. According to The Washington Herald., January 04, 1920, Page 12 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1920-01-04/ed-... Jellicoe's wife had sailed back to England from New York on Jan 3, 1920. She sailed on the Adriatic. It seems likely that the Jellicoes traveled from Ottawa to New York by land. This picture is quite possibly on the Adriatic. Evening star., January 18, 1920, page 70, photo at bottom chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-01-18/ed-... shows Lady Jellicoe just before she sailed. She appears to be wearing the same hat and collar.

Seems to be this photo: "48667. Courtyard with convalescent patients. Camp Hospital No. 46. Landerneau, Finistere, France. January 7, 1919." archive.org/stream/cu31924027944598#page/n513/mode/2up Catalogue of official A.E.F. photographs by United States. War Dept. General Staff; United States. Army. Signal Corps Publication date 1919 ====================================================== "CAMP HOSPITAL NO. 46 Camp Hospital No. 46 was established May 16, 1918, at Landerneau, a small town about 14 miles east of Brest, Department Finistere, base section No. 5. Its personnel were assigned from the American Expeditionary Forces at large. It occupied a part of a large French convent school, the Pensionnat du Calvare, which was suitable for hospital purposes, as it contained many large well lighted and ventilated rooms; however, the sanitary arrangements were exceedingly poor and no adequate water supply existed. A detachment of United States Engineers was attached to the hospital to install the necessary plumbing and to provide a sufficient water supply; also several wooden barracks for the personnel were constructed by the Engineers, and the bed capacity of the hospital was increased from 250 to 300. Camp Hospital No. 46 was intended for convalescent patients only, but it received cases of acute disease and of injury from its surrounding area. During December, 1918, only venereal cases en route to the United States were admitted. The total number of patients admitted during its existence was 1,150. The hospital was closed February 28, 1919, and its personnel were transferred to Camp Pontanezen, Brest, for duty." history.amedd.army.mil/booksdocs/wwi/adminamerexp/chapter... history.amedd.army.mil/booksdocs/wwi/adminamerexp/ch25fig...

Abe Brooks (or Brook, Brock or Bruke) was one of the 249 passengers deported to the Soviet Union in December 1919 aboard the USAT Buford, known as the "Soviet Ark".  Brooks was a member of the Union of Russian Workers, one of the organizations targeted in the Red Scare of 1919-1920 and had been arrested for distributing "anarchist" literature in Union Square.
I wonder what happened to him? Thanks Seuss

see editorsnotes.org/projects/emma/notes/103/

The New-York tribune., December 23, 1919, Image 1, col. 3 (at the bottom) wrote: "It was learned from Federal officials that Abraham Brooks ... was among those deported on the Buford. Brooks was arrested during a riot at a Russian demonstration in Washington Square last October. He was accused of circulating anarchist literature which protested against the presence of American troops in Russia." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-12-23/ed-...

That's how another article on that site captions this: "Emma Goldman's deportation portrait, 1919. In post-World War I America, foreigners and their "foreign ideas" were increasingly untolerated. Following her release from prison in 1919, Goldman was immediately re-arrested on the order of J. Edgar Hoover, then director of intelligence for the U.S. Justice Department. Hoover persuaded the courts to deny Goldman's citizenship claims, thus making her liable to deportation under the 1918 Alien Act, which allowed for the expulsion of any alien found to be an anarchist. On December 21, 1919, Goldman and 248 other foreign-born radicals were deported to the Soviet Union. Courtesy of the Emma Goldman Papers, University of California, Berkeley." jwa.org/thisweek/sep/27/1919/emma-goldman-arrested

"Maurice Polydore Marie Bernard Maeterlinck[1] (also called Comte (Count) Maeterlinck from 1932;] [mo.ʁis ma.tɛʁ.lɛ̃ːk] in Belgium, [mɛ.teʁ.lɛ̃ːk] in France; 29 August 1862 – 6 May 1949) was a Belgian playwright, poet, and essayist who was Flemish but wrote in French. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1911 "in appreciation of his many-sided literary activities, and especially of his dramatic works, which are distinguished by a wealth of imagination and by a poetic fancy, which reveals, sometimes in the guise of a fairy tale, a deep inspiration, while in a mysterious way they appeal to the readers' own feelings and stimulate their imaginations". The main themes in his work are death and the meaning of life. His plays form an important part of the Symbolist movement." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Maeterlinck

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Cooper_Procter From Wikipedia: William Cooper Procter (August 25, 1862 - May 2, 1934) was the grandson of William Procter, the co-founder of Procter & Gamble Co. He was head of the company from 1907 to 1930 and was the last member of the founding families to lead Procter & Gamble.[1] Prior to taking that post, he helped drive the company's creation of a profit-sharing program for employees,[2] the first in America. Procter joined the board of trustees for the Children's Hospital in Cincinnati (now known as Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center). In 1921, Procter was elected president of the new board of trustees, a position he held until his death in 1934. Procter's leadership and philanthropy led to an expansion in the hospital's size, scope, mission and reputation. One of the board's first acts was to change the hospital's name from Protestant Episcopal Hospital to the Children's Hospital. Procter's donation to Princeton University upon his graduation in 1883[3][4] provided for the construction in 1913 of Procter Hall. One of several Gothic buildings designed by Ralph Adams Cram to serve as the new Graduate College, Procter Hall is particularly noted for its Great West Window,[5] designed by William and Anne Lee Willet.[6] Today the building serves as the college's formal dining hall[7] and chief public space.[8]
see also and www.glendaleheritage.org/glendale/events/always-on-displa...

Interesting photo.  The two pennants above the piano are indicative of someone's service in the National Guard.  The upper one says "Tobyhanna, Pa. 1914".  Tobyhanna reservation was an installation where National Guard units conducted artillery live fire practice.  The second pennant says "In remembrance of my life on the Mexican border, 1916" - where National Guard units deployed to guard against incursions by Pancho Villa, et. al.

Since Wolff was a Frenchman who did not come to the U.S. until after World War I, the pennants are probably not his.  Anyone know where the photo might have been taken?

Thanks  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05], We'll include his full name in the catalog record. 

 [https://www.flickr.com/photos/25100796@N08], I saw those pennants also. You are correct. Wolff came over after the war and actually served in the French Army. I searched through some of the New York newspaper society pages in hopes they would mention where he was staying but I had no luck.

This is the first of a series of three photos of activities at a warehouse of the Army Quartermaster's Effects Bureau. The Bureau was in Hoboken, N.J., but also rented warehouse space in New York. [Writing on the crates is "Effects Bureau, 520 [529?] Greenwich St., New York"].[ " The work is increasing to such an extent and the packages are coming so rapidly that Colonel Danforth leased another large warehouse on Greenwich Street New York."] The Effects Bureau managed the personal effects of war dead, returned from the battlefield. Col. Chas. H. Danforth was Chief of the Bureau. American Legion Weekly, July 25, 1919 books.google.com/books?id=IrhCAQAAMAAJ&dq=Effects+Bur... In this photo a worker with a large pot of ink and a brush is apparently writing a shipping address on a crate of effects.
Examining the personal effects of a dead soldier, Army Effects Bureau warehouse, New York City. see
Art Siegel: thank you for the information on these related images. We'll update our records.

The title "52nd Brigade, 25th Division" is incorrect.  The 52nd Brigade was an element of the 26th Division (Order of Battle of the United States Land Forces in the World War, American Expeditionary Forces: Divisions.  Volume 2, Center of Military History, United States Army, Washington, DC, 1988, page 114).  Close examination of the photo indicates that the original caption writer misread the information on the bag in the foreground.
Thanks for catching that error [https://www.flickr.com/photos/25100796@N08]. We'll change the description in the catalog record to say 26th Division.

No Wikipedia article in English, but: ""Gabriella Besanzoni (1890-1962) fue una famosa contralto italiana." es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabriella_Besanzoni "The artist also appeared at the Met opposite Caruso in the season 1919/20, but she was not successful." www.cantabile-subito.de/Mezzo-Sopranos/Besanzoni__Gabriel... forgottenoperasingers.blogspot.com/2016/07/gabriella-besa... "Gabriella Besanzoni (1888—1962) Besanzoni, Gabriella (1888 - 1962), mezzo-soprano, soprano (b Rome, 20 Sept 1888; d Rome, 8 July 1962). Italian mezzo-soprano. She studied in Rome, making her début (as a soprano) as Adalgisa at Viterbo in 1911. After further study she became a mezzo-soprano, singing Ulrica in Rome and appearing throughout Italy. She first sang at the Teatro Colón, Buenos Aires, in 1918, returning there frequently; she also visited Rio de Janeiro and, in 1919, Mexico City, where she sang Ulrica, Delilah, Nancy (Martha), Carmen and Amneris, all with Dnrico Caruso as principal tenor. Engaged at the Metropolitan (1919–20), she made her début as Amneris, then sang Isabella in the Metropolitan première of L’italiana in Algeri, as well as Delilah and Preziosilla (Forza del destino) with Caruso. Besanzoni's repertory also included Laura (La Gioconda) and Santuzza, which she sang at performances of Cavalleria rusticana conducted by Pietro Mascagni himself. At La Scala (1923–4) she sang C. W. Gluck's Orpheus under Toscanini, and also appeared as Mignon and Carmen, the role of her farewell in 1939 at the Baths of Caracalla, Rome. Her voice was rich, powerful, smoothly produced and notably flexible. From The Grove Book of Opera Singers " oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095...

Baritone vocalist and voice teacher who had a studio in New York between 1919 and 1922. (sometimes appears as Ferry Lulek. Musical Courier article, accompanied by and Underwood & Underwod photo, from July 3, 1919: "DR FERY LULEK TO SETTLE IN NEW YORK Prominent Vocal Teacher and Singer Assured of an Immense Class The good news is at hand that the list of New York's famous vocal pedagogues is to be augmented by the permanent presence here of Dr Fery Lulek, late of the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music where he taught with such brilliant results for seven years that every effort was made to induce him to remain there. However as Dr Lulek also is a concert singer of high attainments, he felt that further connection with the constant duties of so large an institution as that in Cincinnati and longer residence away from metropolitan atmosphere and music life were not conducive to the advancement of his own larger career. Therefore Dr Lulek made up his mind to dwell henceforth in New York and to act more or less as a free lance with his eye chiefly on his activity as a soloist. However when it became known that he contemplated such a move, so many were the lesson applications from his old students and from numerous new ones that he found himself compelled to plan for extensive pedagogical work and to change his original purpose of taking only a few pupils and spending most of his time in concert traveling, When Dr Lulek opens his new studios here next fall he will have a class so large that the musical circles of this city are sure to marvel. Dr Lulek's standing in the profession is well known to MUSICAL Courier readers but perhaps a few words about him biographically may not be amiss at this time. Dr Fery Lulek's father, a distinguished lawyer, chose notwithstanding his son's very pronounced musical gifts which early presaged a brilliant musical career, what he considered to be a more practical profession for his son namely the law. Therefore after having finished his academic studies Fery Lulek became a student of law. He was graduated and took his degree in 1899. For the next four years he devoted himself to the practice of his chosen profession in the character of judge as well as lawyer. In the meantime however he had been pursuing his musical studies under the guidance of Professor Kraemer and later under Professor Gaensbacher and Professor Ress. In 1904 Dr Lulek went to Paris to take up his studies with Sbriglia, the well known Italian teacher of De Reszke, Plançon, etc and since that time he has devoted himself entirely to music having appeared with flattering success both as a concert and oratorio singer in all the leading cities of France, England, Belgium, Denmark, Austria and Germany. Dr Lulek sang before the President of France and in recognition of his services to the Universite Populaire was in the same year decorated by the government and made an Officer de l'Academie Francaise. Dr Lulek came to America to fill a series of concert engagements in the summer of 1912 and was repeatedly heard in Newport, as also in Bar Harbor and Toronto, meeting with immediate emphatic success. In connection with his pedagogical activities he continued his concert work which in his first American tour 1913 included prominent solo and orchestral engagements and appearances at the Toronto Festival and in the New York Metropolitan Opera concert series. In January 1912 Bertha Baur directress of the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music met Dr Lulek in New York and succeeded in engaging him as head of her vocal department. In the meantime his concert engagements have continued with such organizations as the St Louis and Cincinnati Symphony orchestras with unvarying acclaim. His remarkable success in developing voices is endorsed by many leading musicians, composers, directors and singers including such authorities as Victor Herbert, Dr Stillman Kelly,Henry Hadley, P.A. Tirindelli, Nahan Franko, John Cort, etc. Over fifty Lulek pupils have been placed as teachers in leading musical institutions throughout the country, others have operatic contracts, while still others are soloists in churches and upon the concert stage. The Lulek voice is a sympathetic smooth and exquisitely cultivated baritone of big power and he uses his organ with the most tactful and finished art New York audiences will have a chance to welcome this proved teacher and accomplished concert artist and to judge him anew when he reappears here at Aeolian Hall in his two recitals next October and March." He had a recital at New York's Aeolian hall in November, 1919. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A00E2D71031E0... In July, 1922, he joined the Chicago Musical College books.google.com/books?id=bmhFAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA73&lp...

"Alice Ames Winter (1865-1944) was a Wellesley College graduate, teacher, novelist, and popular public speaker. She was president of the first Woman's Club of Minneapolis and was active in the Unitarian church. Some of her publications include The Prize to the Hardy (1905), Jewel Weed (1906), and The Business of Being a Club Woman (1925)." www.publicbookshelf.com/author/Alice-Ames-Winter "Alice Ames Winter, ninth international president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, 1920—1924. During her term, Alice greatly increased membership and brought the state organizations closer." (with photo) www.gfwc.org/exhibits-microsite/vex2/0A0A29C7-A1C6-42F7-8... "Alice Ames Winter (Mrs. Thomas Gerald Winter) was born in Albany, New York. Although she lived in various places throughout her childhood, most of it was spent in the Boston, Massachusetts, area. After graduating from Wellesley College with both a B.A. and an M.A., she married and moved to Minneapolis, Minnesota. Active in civic affairs, she founded and headed the Minneapolis Woman's Club for eight years. In 1914 Winter became chairman of GFWC's Department of Literature. At the beginning of World War I, she was made chairman of the Americanization effort. She was elected as GFWC President in 1920. During her term, Alice Winter greatly increased membership and brought the state organizations closer. The GFWC Headquarters building at 1734 N Street, NW, in Washington, D.C., was purchased during her administration. She was also appointed by President Harding to the advisory committee for the Conference on Naval Disarmament held in Washington, D.C., 1921-1922. After her GFWC presidency, Winter was a contributing editor to the Ladies Home Journal for four years. In 1929, she accepted a position with the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America. She moved to Pasadena, California, and remained at this job for thirteen years, working toward a higher standard for motion pictures. In addition to her numerous magazine articles, Winter also published two novels: The Prize to the Hardy (1905) and Jewel Weed (1906). Alice Ames Winter died 5 May 1943." gfwc.pastperfectonline.com/byperson?keyword=Winter%2C+Ali... Her grave: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=winter...;

"Nancy Witcher Langhorne Astor, Viscountess Astor, CH (19 May 1879 – 2 May 1964) was the first female Member of Parliament to take her seat.** in the election of November, 1919. She was an American citizen who moved to England at age 26. She made a second marriage to Waldorf Astor as a young woman in England. After he succeeded to the peerage and entered the House of Lords, she entered politics, in 1919 winning his former seat in Plymouth and becoming the first woman to sit as a Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons.[Note 1] Her first husband was an American citizen, Robert Gould Shaw II, and they divorced. She served in Parliament as a member of the Conservative Party for Plymouth Sutton until 1945, when she was persuaded to step down. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Astor,_Viscountess_Astor ** She became the first woman to take up her seat in the Commons (the first woman to be elected, Countess Markievicz, the Sinn Féin MP for Dublin St Patrick's, refused to take her seat). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plymouth_Sutton_by-election,_1919

"Pietro Cimara (1887 in Rome – 1967 in Milan) was an Italian composer, conductor and pianist. He was a student of Respighi at the Accademia di Santa Cecilia in Rome. His output included many songs. He was published by Francesco Bongiovanni of Bologna. From 1950-1957 he was conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, where he had a stroke in 1957 while conducting La Forza del Destino, after which he retired to Italy." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietro_Cimara This may have been taken in New York, where he appeared accompanying Luisa Tetrazzini (on piano) at the Hippodrome on Nov. 30, 1919, and a subsequent national tour. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A03E7D7153BEE... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1920-01-07/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042345/1920-01-26/ed-... gallery.multcolib.org/document/luisa-tetrazzini-soprano-p...

As to whether he was a Count, and she a Countess, this from a 2003 biography: "The Cimara family was somehow connected to aristocracy but the relationship is unclear. Nevertheless, Luigi is said to have been of aristocratic stature, and in Charles Neilson Gattey’s Luisa Tetrazzini the Florentine Nightingale, Pietro is referred to as “Count Cimara.” "As little has been written about Cimara’s personality, even less has been documented about his wife. Cimara was married to M. Clara Cassini,47 who, when mentioned in various newspaper articles and stories, is referred to merely as Cimara’s wife, Clara. The only other information provided about her comes from a 1919 Ellis Island Passenger Record which documents that she was Italian, married, 25 years old--thus making her year of birth either 1893 or 1894, and that her place of residence was London, England." According to this source, the Cimaras arrived in New York aboard the Mauretania on November 25, 1919. (p. 18) repositories.lib.utexas.edu/bitstream/handle/2152/12922/r...

"ROSALIE MILLER [s]. New York City (?), 1888- 1972. A concert singer active in the New York area in the ‘teens and ‘20s, Miller also occasionally appeared in opera, for example having sung Pamina in the 1925 Baden-Baden Mozart Festival. The same year she also appeared in five recitals in London and fifteen in Paris, as well as in Dresden and Berlin. Earlier, during the seasons of 1918-20, she had been on the Metropolitan Opera roster appearing only on two Sunday evening Concerts. In the first she sang an aria from Hérodiade and the second “Pleurez, mes yeux” from Le Cid, as well both evenings interesting groupings of songs. Miller taught at Juilliard (then the NY Institute of Musical Art), at the opera workshop program of the Henry Street Settlement in NYC and privately from her home on 68th Street. One of her pupils was soprano Anne Bollinger. " holdridgerecords.com/auction_pdfs/12.3_Cylinders_Pathes_E...

Rosalie Miller using what appears to be a music typewriter. I've been unable to identify the model – and there were only a handful c.1918, so perhaps this is not a music typewriter. While there are many sources ... the one I've found more appropriate to music typewriters is from Music Printing History.

Not a music typewriter, "This machine is the Blick Featherweight and is a development of the earlier Model 5 with an aluminium frame. Possibly the lightest portable typewriter ever produced, the Featherweight was marketed as the 'Five Pound Secretary'. " It had a changeable typewheel, too. Photos and a detailed description of how it worked at collections.museumvictoria.com.au/items/388118 1915 ad: books.google.com/books?id=dndQAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA68&am...
Flicker user César Astudillo

Nicely done [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]!    It's just like you!  ;)

I love the photograph by César Astudillo!  It's so interesting that there were these "featherweight" typewriters early on, and they seemingly just became bigger and heavier through the years.  And the similarity between the Blick's rotating type wheel (1910) and IBM Selectric's type balls 50 years later is amazing. (Blick offered 170 different type wheels according to the ad you found!)

As an aside, while searching earlier for music typewriters I noted that "type writer" appears to have begun as two words... and followed the usual sequence of becoming hyphenated and then one word -- albeit over a relatively short timeline.

I love the photograph by César Astudillo!  It's so interesting that there were these "featherweight" typewriters early on, and they seemingly just became bigger and heavier through the years.  And the similarity between the Blick's rotating type wheel (1910) and IBM Selectric's type balls 50 years later is amazing. (Blick offered 170 different type wheels according to the ad you found!)

As an aside, while searching earlier for music typewriters I noted that "type writer" appears to have begun as two words... and followed the usual sequence of becoming hyphenated and then one word -- albeit over a relatively short timeline.

That typewheel is pretty amazing.  I also like that there is no ribbon, and the typewheel inks itself on an ink roller, held up by that big metal arc piece, on the way down to the paper.

There are a lot of words like that, aren't there?  The hyphen from email seems to have finally disappeared.

Thanks for identifying the typist and the machine (in addition to the two word/one word issues, the person also used to be called a typewriter! en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typewriter ). We'll add information to the description at our end.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/barbara_loc], well I just spent 45+ minutes going down that Wikipedia rabbit hole -- including following a couple of "tunnels" that intersected said rabbit hole ;) I now know more about typewriters than I could have ever imagined I would ;) Who knew that the early 'failures' of electric typewriters gaining popularity was because different (US) cities used different voltages! And ... <-- pun intended, discovered along said rabbit-hole-tunnel, I learned that the ampersand was once the 27th 'letter' of our alphabet (along with two other letters that were removed).
"In the early 1800s, school children reciting their ABCs concluded the alphabet with the &. It would have been confusing to say “X, Y, Z, and.” Rather, the students said, “and per se and.” “Per se” means “by itself,” so the students were essentially saying, “X, Y, Z, and by itself and.” Over time, “and per se and” was slurred together into the word we use today: ampersand." – blog.dictionary.com/ampersand/
So for those 45+ minutes I'll never get back, I thank you! ;)

The Evening star., August 07, 1919, Image 8, "Society" mentions a Senora de Sol, wife of Don Salvador Sol M, minister of Salvador to the United States chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1919-08-07/ed-...

OK, that's correct. This photo, cropped, appeared inThe Washington times., September 11, 1919 and The Washington (D.C.) Evening Star., January 16, 1920, with the captions: "MME. SALVADOR SOL, Wife of the minister of Salvador, who will assist Mrs. Alice Pike Barney in her tea and auction sale of seats and boxes for the actors' benefit." and "MME. SALVADOR SOL. Wife of the minister of Salvador, who will entertain the wife of the President of Salvador." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1919-09-11/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-01-16/ed-...

Don Salvador Sol and his wife were in Washington a little over a year. In August, 1920, he resigned his post and they returned to Salvador the following month to resume their lives as coffee plantation owners with intentions of building the country's first sugar mill. The Washington times., August 15, 1920 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-08-15/ed-... A photo of Don Salvador Sol at a Washington function in June, 1919: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/npc2007018709/

She was the former Eva Duke, born in Salvador but raised and educated in California.
(San Francisco Chronicle, 7-21-1918, p. 13.)
According to www.geni.com Eva Duke Carazo, wife of Salvador Sol Millet.

Carazo was her parental name, so she was Eva Sol C. Millet was his, so he was Salvador Sol M., as in your first comment above. Those final names aren't used for most purposes. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_naming_customs.
Thanks for identifying her and tracing her names and published versions of the photo. We'll add information at our end.

John Stetson, the manager, said there was a fortune in her laugh. A few will remember her debut in "The Crust of Society." She was a star and a celebrated character actress. But things went wrong. She has become an agent for a typewriting machine." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1920-01-25/ed-... Elna Munch (Elna Elisabeth Munch) (née Sarauw).  In 1896 she graduated with an M.Sc. degree in mathematics from Kbh.s University (Copenhagen University). In 1902 she married Peter Munch (1870-1948), who was later Denmark's foreign minister from 1929-1940.   They had one son Ebbe Helge Munch (1904-1976) whom I presume is the child sitting in Elna Munch's lap in this photograph. It appears that a different cropped version of this photograph is in the journal "Kvinden og Samfundet" ("Woman and Society, KvS"), no. 4, 1909.  [1] [2]

"US Congresswoman. The daughter of US Senator Marcus A. Hanna, she was educated in private schools in Ohio, New York and Connecticut, and then became owner and operator of a Byron, Illinois dairy farm. Married to Congressman and Senator Joseph Medill McCormick, who was from a family prominent in newspaper publishing, she was also active in newspapers as President of Rockford's Consolidated Newspapers, Inc. Long active in the women's suffrage movement, in 1919 she became Chairman of the Republican National Committee's newly-formed Woman's Executive Committee, serving until 1924. In 1924 she was elected Republican National Committeewoman from Illinois, a position she held until 1928. Her husband was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the US Senate in 1924 and committed suicide in 1925. In 1928 she was elected to the US House of Representatives and served one term, 1929 to 1931. In 1930 she was the unsuccessful Republican nominee for US Senator, afterwards returning to her newspaper interests. In 1932 she married Albert Gallatin Simms, Congressman and Republican National Committee member from New Mexico." www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=6886257 Her official Congressional bio entry: McCORMICK, Ruth Hanna, (1880 - 1944) McCORMICK, Ruth Hanna, (daughter of Marcus Alonzo Hanna, wife of Joseph Medill McCormick and of Albert Gallatin Simms), a Representative from Illinois; born in Cleveland, Ohio, March 27, 1880; attended Hathaway Brown School in Cleveland, Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) School, and Miss Porter’s School in Farmington, Conn.; owned and operated a dairy and breeding farm near Byron, Ill.; publisher and president of the Rockford Consolidated Newspapers (Inc.), Rockford, Ill.; chairman of the first woman’s executive committee of the Republican National Committee, and an associate member of the national committee 1919-1924, in the latter year becoming the first elected national committeewoman from Illinois and served until 1928; active worker for the suffrage amendment from 1913 until the Constitution was amended; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-first Congress (March 4, 1929-March 3, 1931); was not a candidate for renomination in 1930, having received the Republican nomination for United States Senator, in which election she was unsuccessful; resumed her newspaper interests; married Albert Gallatin Simms, of New Mexico, who was also a Member of the Seventy-first Congress; and resided in Albuquerque, N.Mex.; died in Chicago, Ill., on December 31, 1944; interment in Fairview Cemetery, Albuquerque, N.Mex. Bibliography ”Ruth Hanna McCormick” in Women in Congress, 1917-2006. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2006. bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000372 see also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Hanna_McCormick

The Chambers and Madison Streets streetcar line (aka Madison Street line) of the New York Railways was discontinued on Sept. 21, 1919. Cars on this line were battery powered. metro.wikia.com/wiki/List_of_streetcar_lines_in_Manhattan. This line ran east to west from the Grand St. Ferry on the East River to the Chambers St. Ferry on the Hudson, roughly on the route of the present day M22 bus line. books.google.com/books?id=2DA05tBefEsC&pg=PA888&l... metro.wikia.com/wiki/List_of_streetcar_lines_in_Manhattan It's possible this photo was taken to illustrate a story about the last day of the line's service. Alfred A. "Al" Bernard (1888-1949) was an American vaudeville singer, known as "The Boy From Dixie", who was most popular during the 1910s through early 1930s. Born in New Orleans, Louisiana, Bernard became a blackface singer in minstrel shows before starting his recording career around 1916.   Bernard composed and recorded more than 100 songs in the first three decades of the 20th century.   He was one of the first white singers to record blues songs.   W. C. Handy credited Bernard with helping his own career by recording a number of his songs, notably "St. Louis Blues".  Bernard recorded the song for nine different record labels, the most successful being what Handy called "the sensational Victor recording in which he sang with the Dixieland Jazz Band". For a brief period in the early 20's Bernard was teamed with Jimmy Durante and wrote the lyrics for "Papa String Bean" for Durante.  He teamed up with the ragtime composer J. Russell Robinson in a vaudeville team called the Dixie Stars and they recorded songs together for a number of famous labels.  Bernard usually sang while Robinson played the piano and added some vocals. Together they composed a number of hit songs including "Blue Eyed Sally" and "Let Me Be The First To Kiss You Good Morning".   Excerpted – [1] [2]
He was recording for Victor starting in 1919: adp.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/talent/detail/1835/Bernard...

"Edgar Algernon Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, CH, PC, QC (14 September 1864 – 24 November 1958), known as Lord Robert Cecil from 1868 to 1923, was a British lawyer, politician and diplomat. He was one of the architects of the League of Nations and a defender of it, whose service to the organisation saw him awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1937." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cecil,_1st_Viscount_Cecil_of...

New York State's first female judge. Unfortunately, she was removed from the bench, for improper conduct, in 1931. "MAYOR APPOINTS MRS. JEAN NORRIS CITY MAGISTRATE Mayor Hylan today appointed Mrs. Jean H. Norrls a City Magistrate for a period of thirty days to fill the vacancy caused by the illness of Magistrate Matthew P. Breen. She will be assigned to the Woman's Court. Mrs. Norrls appeared at City Hall and was immediately sworn in by the Mayor. She has the honor of being the flrst woman ever selected to sit on the Judge's bench in a criminal or civil court In this State." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1919-10-27/ed-... The evening world., October 27, 1919 New York Times story: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9805EFDD1138EE...
